07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: All men are sinners, the Fathers of the Faith teach us. Even the noblest of kings and the most chivalrous of knights may find themselves overcome by rage and lust and envy, and commit acts that shame them and tarnish their good names. And the vilest of men and the wickedest of women likewise may do good from time to time, for love and compassion and pity may be found in even the blackest of hearts. “We are as the gods made us,” wrote Septon Barth, the wisest man ever to serve as the Hand of the King, “strong and weak, good and bad, cruel and kind, heroic and selfish. Know that if you would rule over the kingdoms of men.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The Fathers of the Faith taught us to be good and noble even when we find ourselves overcome by our own dark passions. Even the noblest of kings had a capacity for sin, one that could oftentimes have dire consequences if they were to commit atrocities like rage, lust or envy. In such moments, even the strongest can become his weakest while a wicked woman can sometimes do more good than bad, and vice versa. Cruelty knows no gender or class distinction; anyone could show heroic traits in one matter but be selfish in another. All too often those from all walks of life tarnish their reputations with one misstep that leads them into the blackest of pits where it is hard to ever crawl out from again.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Seldom was the truth of his words seen as clearly as during the 50th year after Aegon’s Conquest. As the new year dawned, all across the realm plans were being made to mark a half century of Targaryen rule over Westeros with feasts, fairs, and tourneys. The horrors of King Maegor’s rule were receding into the past, the Iron Throne and the Faith were reconciled, and the young King Jaehaerys I was the darling of smallfolk and great lords alike from Oldtown to the Wall. Yet unbeknownst to all but a few, storm clouds were gathering on the horizon, and faintly in the distance wise men could hear a rumble of thunder.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Aegon and Maegor, along with Jaehaerys I, conquered Westeros during the 'Conquest', an event that would later mark the half century of a new young king ruling and wise councilors gathering. As they heard tales from Father of the Faith and old maester's journals to learn what it meant to be both noble as well as courageous, even in the face of grevious evil which looked to tarnish it at every turn—from vilest of men to wickedest of women—they also found themselves overcome by their own temptations; rage, lust and envy were in constant battle for good against bad. But amid this blackest of times, these most chivalrous knights found strength within themselves when weak - heroic yet selfish - and eventually able to do good not only for Westeros but Oldtown, The Wall or beyond.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: A realm with two kings is like a man with two heads, the smallfolk are wont to say. In 50 AC, the realm of Westeros found itself blessed with one king, a Hand, and three queens, as in King Maegor’s day…but whereas Maegor’s queens had been consorts, subservient to his will, living and dying at his whim, each of the queens of the half-century was a power in her own right.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: It was the year 50 AC, a time of blessed subservience for Maegor in Westeros who felt that he was truly living during his best days; though, it is said that the dying wish of Lord Stark was to bring down this reign. For two queens, Alyssa Velaryon and Rhaena Targaryen, were about to arise as possible candidates for Queen in the West. Unfortunately for them, however, Maegor viewed them both with suspicion and treated both ladies as if they were inferior to him—the vilest of men. Little did he know how much danger Lady Lucinda Tully had placed upon Westeros by gathering nobles from Oldtown and beyond at her ferry landing near Gods Eye—a gathering undone within a blink by an unexpected receding storm triggered by Dreamfyre.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: In the Red Keep of King’s Landing sat the Queen Regent Alyssa, widow of the late King Aenys, mother to his son Jaehaerys, and wife to the King’s Hand, Rogar Baratheon. Just across Blackwater Bay on Dragonstone, a younger queen had arisen when Alyssa’s daughter Alysanne, a maid of thirteen years, had pledged her troth to her brother King Jaehaerys, against the wishes of her mother and her mother’s lord husband. And far to the west on Fair Isle, with the whole width of Westeros separating her from both mother and sister, was Alyssa’s eldest daughter, the dragonrider Rhaena Targaryen, widow of Prince Aegon the Uncrowned. In the westerlands, riverlands, and parts of the Reach, men were already calling her the Queen in the West.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa Velaryon had pledged her troth to King Aenys only a few months prior, but Jaehaerys, Rogar Baratheon and Alysanne Targaryen were already on their way towards the Red Keep of King’s Landing. There was much discontent among the smallfolk across Westeros, but His Grace chose to stand surety for his son with haste. The lords and ladies from Blackwater Bay, Dragonstone, Fair Isle and more sat anxiously as Prince Aegon and Rhaena Targaryen had arisen anew within their villages - two queens blessing them with living faeries dying just as soon as they'd been born.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Two sisters and a mother, the three queens were bound by blood and grief and suffering…and yet between them lay shadows old and new, growing darker by the day. The amity and unity of purpose that had enabled Jaehaerys, his sisters, and their mother to topple Maegor the Cruel had begun to fray, as long-simmering resentments and divisions made themselves felt. For the remainder of the regency the boy king and his little queen would find themselves deeply at odds with the King’s Hand and the Queen Regent, in a rivalry that would continue into Jaehaerys’s own reign and threaten to plunge the Seven Kingdoms back into war.*1
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The two sisters, Alysanne and Rhaena Targaryen had pledged their troth alongside King Aenys, Jaehaerys and three queens—Alyssa Velaryon, along with Queen Elinor of House Farman and Queen Alys of the Seven Kingdoms—to topple Maegor the Cruel. Bound by a common faith to lay aside their rivalries in the old wars and unite against a darker fate, they found themselves confronting relentless grief, suffering, and bone-tired fatigue from long miles traveled since leaving Westeros. The Red Keep of King’s Landing was now beneath them as they set out for Blackwater Bay on Dreamfyre with Lord Rogar Baratheon at the helm. How would this ancient fraternity - bound by blood - find justice for all?

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The immediate cause of the tension was the king’s sudden and secret marriage to his sister, which had taken the Hand and the Queen Regent unawares and thrown their own plans and schemes into disarray. It would be a mistake to believe that was the sole cause of the estrangement, however; the other weddings that had made 49 AC the Year of the Three Brides had also left scars.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The King and Hand of the Seven Kingdoms had spoken. A secret marriage was to be taken, one strategic enough to unite every corner of Westeros in a swift blow, through common bonds of family. The sudden plan threw a flurry of weddings into motion; Queen Regent Alysanne Targaryen ensured all moved according to her own planning — for she held the responsibility now that Jaehaerys, the king loving known as the 'Conciliator', had passed away along with his beloved Four-headed Beast and Dreamfyre. Lady Lucinda Tully was amongst those thrown suddenly into marriage negotiations and secret engagements; soon she would join Lord Rogar Baratheon at Stonedance Castle, beyond which lay a darkness far darker than any in recent memory for both herself and Westeros alike.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Lord Rogar had never asked Jaehaerys for leave to wed his mother, an omission the boy king took for a sign of disrespect. Moreover, His Grace did not approve of the match; as he would later confess to Septon Barth, he valued Lord Rogar as a counselor and friend, but he did not need a second father, and thought his own judgment, temperament, and intelligence to be superior to his Hand’s. Jaehaerys also felt he should have been consulted about his sister Rhaena’s marriage, though he felt that slight less keenly. Queen Alyssa, for her part, was deeply hurt that she had neither been advised of nor invited to Rhaena’s wedding on Fair Isle.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon and Queen Alyssa had traveled to Fair Isle to be wed, a marriage that would unite two powerful families. Lord Rogar asked Jaehaerys, the Hand of the King, to approve this sudden union which he did in secret - much to the Queen Regent's chagrin. Lord Rogar valued Queen Alyssa greatly, but this was more than an act of love; they both needed each other strategically and consulted with their allies before making a final decision - omitting others who were hurt by this perceived sign of disrespect. Septon Barth served as their second father throughout these nuptials and often provided sage advice on how best to go about it according to tradition.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Away in the west, Rhaena Targaryen nursed her own grievances. As she confided to the old friends and favorites she had gathered around her, Queen Rhaena neither understood nor shared her mother’s affection for Rogar Baratheon. Though she honored him grudgingly for rising in support of her brother Jaehaerys against their uncle Maegor, his inaction when her own husband, Prince Aegon, faced Maegor in the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye was something she could neither forget nor forgive. Also, with the passage of time Queen Rhaena grew ever more resentful that her own claim to the Iron Throne, and that of her daughters, had been disregarded in favor of that of “my baby brother” (as she was wont to call Jaehaerys). She was the firstborn, she reminded those who would listen, and had been a dragonrider before any of her siblings, yet all of them and “even my own mother” had conspired to pass her over.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: With the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye looming in the West, Rhaena Targaryen found her relationship with her betrothed Lord Rogar Baratheon tested. He was a respected warrior and his friends, like Maegor and Prince Aegon, had nursed resentful feelings against him for years due to his honoring of Rhaena above them. Yet despite this slight, he accepted Jaehaerys' wish for them to wed and asked for everyone's approval before confessing his undying love for her. Though hurt by his omission of seeking her father's consultation first, she knew he valued her opinion immensely and felt that need as if it were a sign of respect from a second father. She chose to forgive him so they could go forward with their marriage plans but also reminded herself never to forget what he had done; never fully able to let go of old grievances against those who were once favorites.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Looking back now with the benefit of hindsight, it is easy to say that Jaehaerys and Alysanne had the right of it in the conflicts that arose during the last year of their mother’s regency, and to cast Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar as villains. That is how the singers tell the tale, certainly; the swift and sudden marriage of Jaehaerys and Alysanne was a romance unequaled since the days of Florian the Fool and his Jonquil, to hear them sing of it. And in songs, as ever, love conquers all. The truth, we submit, is a deal less simple. Queen Alyssa’s misgivings about the match grew out of genuine concern for her children, the Targaryen dynasty, and the realm as a whole. Nor were her fears without foundation.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys and Alysanne looked back on their conquest with a proud yet solemn cast. Queen Alyssa never liked to talk about the battles, but Lord Rogar was quick to tell anyone who would listen of Jaehaerys' swift victory at the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye. Florian the Fool was often heard singing of its unequaled valour, and even Jonquil, their own daughter cast aside in favor of other more favored friends could not deny its genuine magnificence.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Lord Rogar Baratheon’s motives were less selfless. A proud man, he had been stunned and angered by the “ingratitude” of the boy king he had regarded as a son, and humiliated when forced to back down at the gates of Dragonstone before half a hundred of his men. A warrior to the bone, Rogar had once dreamed of facing Maegor the Cruel in single combat, and could not stomach being shamed by a lad of fifteen years. Lest we think too harshly of him, however, we would do well to remember Septon Barth’s words. Though he would do some cruel, foolish, and evil things during his last year as Hand, he was not a cruel or evil man at heart, nor even a fool; he had been a hero once, and we must remember that even as we look at the darkest year of his life.
events: Humiliated when forced to back down at the gates of Dragonstone before half a hundred of his men.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon stood, humiliated when forced to back down at the gates of Dragonstone before half a hundred of his men. He dreamed that he would have conquered it with swift and sudden strength unequaled in Westeros, but alas--it was not to be. Maegor the Cruel stood by him insufferably selfless and proud in his ingratitude for another's generosity, foolishly taunting much larger forces than he had with his own evil designs. EvenSepton Barth shook his head tiredly; he must remember that what appeared genuine kindness sometimes bred cruelty of a different kind.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: In the immediate aftermath of his confrontation with Jaehaerys, Lord Rogar could think of little else but the humiliation he had suffered. His lordship’s first impulse was to return to Dragonstone with more men, enough to overwhelm the castle garrison and resolve the situation by force. As for the Kingsguard, Lord Rogar reminded the council that the White Swords had sworn to lay down their lives for the king and “I shall be pleased to give them that honor.” When Lord Tully pointed out that Jaehaerys could simply close the gates of Dragonstone against them, Lord Rogar was undeterred. “Let him. I can take the castle by storm if need be.” In the end only Queen Alyssa could reach his lordship through his wroth and dissuade him from this folly. “My love,” she said softly, “my children ride dragons, and we do not.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon and Maegor the Cruel had humiliated Lord Rogar when they forced him to back down at the gates of Dragonstone before half a hundred of his men, yet he remained undeterred in his own pledge. He called forth Jaehaerys Osgrey, his sworn Rider of White Horse and two other Lords of houses Tully and Stark - Queen Alyssa into immediate action, along with Septon Barth to accompany them. Though their forces were little compared to overwhelm the ones inside the castle; still they rode off on horseback impatiently, pleased that Lord Rogar was not going let an ingratitude go unpunished. As soon as they entered the great hall they saw who being rewarded by a fool's foolishness met fairness with cruelty and selflessness with pride. Little did this group know what would follow next in this confrontation but all knew things were about to get quite out of hand - even Lady Lucinda, author of "A Caution for Young Girls", who watched from corner helplessly hoping her father Lyman Lannister could help their cause bettering than any other most chivalrous knight watching it all happen from aside.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The Queen Regent, no less than her husband, wished to have the king’s rash marriage undone, for she was convinced that word of it would once again set the Faith against the Crown. Her fears were fanned by Septon Mattheus; once away from Jaehaerys, and secure in the knowledge that his lips would not be sewn shut, the septon found his tongue again, and spoke of little else but how “all decent folk” would condemn the king’s incestuous union.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The Queen Regent, Septon Mattheus and young Jaehaerys were discussing the king's rash marriage when they wished to have set an example of decency in Westeros were fanning the found. "It is less than ideal," spoke Septon Mattheus softly, undeterred by the dissatisfied murmurs of Lord Rogar and Queen Alyssa who had been present for their confrontation earlier at Dragonstone. Jaehaerys nodded somberly, overwhelmed yet pleased that his little queen, Coryanne of House Wylde who was much respected by all in the court, was now his wife; Lyman Lannister, one of the most chivalrous knights in Westeros just a day before had formally declared them man and wife at Faircastle amidst friends and family—an event that cemented what many had thought to be an impossible union between a Targaryen King and a daughter from House Farman.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Had Jaehaerys and Alysanne returned to King’s Landing in time to celebrate the new year, as Queen Alyssa prayed (“They will come to their senses and repent this folly,” she told the council), reconciliation might have been possible, but that did not happen. When a fortnight came and went and then another, and still the king did not reappear at court, Alyssa announced her intention to return to Dragonstone, this time alone, to beg her children to come home. Lord Rogar angrily forbade it. “If you go crawling back to him, the boy will never listen to you again,” he said. “He has put his own desires ahead of the good of the realm, and that cannot be allowed. Do you want him to end as his father did?” And so the queen bent to his will and did not go.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: When Jaehaerys and Alysanne returned to King's Landing for the new year celebration, Queen Alyssa and the council thought that their reconciliation was the perfect chance for them to come to their senses. Lord Rogar announced that all affairs from king's rash marriage ought be archived until it passes a decent court of law. He also forbade anyone mentioning Jaehaerys's name in court, including his own daughter Lady Lucinda. As prayers were said throughout Dragonstone and King’s Landing, everything seemed right again in Westeros as memories of resentments faded away - hopefulness surged through citizens' heart like wildfire fanned by the north wind. Alas! Lady Coryanne of House Wylde had other plans; she had crawled back to him with a familiar scheme: one none could have wished nor even hinted - save vilest of men, Pate the Woodcock himself!

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: “That Queen Alyssa wished to do the right thing, no man should doubt,” Septon Barth wrote years later. “Sad to say, however, she oft seemed at a loss as to what that thing might be. She desired above all to be loved, admired, and praised, a yearning she shared with King Aenys, her first husband. A ruler must sometimes do things that are necessary but unpopular, however, though he knows that opprobrium and censure must surely follow. These things Queen Alyssa could seldom bring herself to do.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa watched as Septon Barth walked away, turning her mind to the upcoming events of the new year celebration. Though she doubted such a thing was possible, she desired peace and agreement between King Aenys and Lord Rogar in order for it to take place - though it may be unpopular, a Targaryen Queen must always follow what is right. It made her so sad that often times, doing what's necessary means disregarding how one feels about it. Surely this reconciliation was for the greater good; she must do whatever is necessary if they were ever going to come to their senses and repent from their reckless mistakes.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Days passed and turned to weeks and thence to fortnights, whilst hearts hardened and men grew more resolute on both sides of Blackwater Bay. The boy king and his little queen remained on Dragonstone, awaiting the day when Jaehaerys would take the rule of the Seven Kingdoms in his own hands. Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar continued to hold the reins of power in King’s Landing, searching for a way to undo the king’s marriage and avert the calamity they were certain was to come. Aside from the council, they told no one of what had transpired on Dragonstone, and Lord Rogar commanded the men who had accompanied them to speak no word of what they had seen, at the penalty of losing their tongues. Once the marriage had been annulled, his lordship reasoned, it would be as if it had never happened so far as most of Westeros was concerned…so long as it remained secret. Until the union was consummated, it could still easily be set aside.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003:
Jaehaerys had grown up in Dragonstone, and although King Aenys had annulled his marriage to Queen Alyssa, the young prince still remained loyal to his little queen. Lord Rogar of Blackwater Bay was a hard man who held fast to the rules of chivalry; thus, when Jaehaerys commanded that he remain in King's Landing as Hand until her death, he obeyed. His reasonings passed largely unheard among the courtiers but it was surely unpopular among those that knew how loved he was by the small queen. Despite their fears of what may come to pass once she passed away, they were all sure of one thing: Jaehaerys’ love for Queen Alyssa had never been consummated, and it grew day by day. 

The dragon-lord now told more than ever about stories involving Ser Borys Baratheon—the most chivalrous knight at times considered even more noble than Lyman Lannister—who rode off with Young Lady Coryanne Wylde from House Wylde into the night against her family’s wishes during Maegor The Cruel's reign as His Grace. When asked why he would risk himself so much for such an unpopular cause, Borys simply replied “It is necessary we follow what is right oft when it is unpopular else our sorrow shall grow past measure."

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: This would prove to be a vain hope, as we know now, but to Rogar Baratheon in 50 AC it seemed possible. For a time he must surely have drawn encouragement from the king’s own silence. Jaehaerys had moved swiftly to marry Alysanne, but having done the deed he seemed in no great haste to announce it. He certainly had the means to do so, had he so desired. Maester Culiper, still spry at eighty, had been serving since Queen Visenya’s day, and was ably assisted by two younger maesters. Dragonstone had a full complement of ravens. At a word from Jaehaerys, his marriage could have been proclaimed from one end of the realm to the other. He did not speak that word.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon commanded that his son, Rogar, marry the king's daughter, Jaehaerys. Queen Visenya had grown close to the young man and sought to prove that he was worthy of a Targaryen princess, so she moved swiftly in setting their marriage to be consummated. Maester Culiper advised against it since Lord Rogar had already been married once before; however, his little queen Alysanne could not help but feel drawn to this man and reasoned for them to have a means at serving each other through wedlock. With her encouragement an announcement was made and soon rumors spread throughout Dragonstone of the marital union between King Jaehaerys's daughter and Lady Lucinda Tully’s cousin from highgarden. In order for everyone in Westeros to believe this newfound alliance amongst houses Targaryen and Tully there must have been efforts assisted by those closest around them: Ser Borys Baratheon of house Baratheon offered guidance as did two sisters from House Farman who were Novices at Castle Dragonstone: Edyth and Elissa Farman, known as Alysanne's familiars.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Scholars have debated ever since as to the reasons for his silence. Was he repenting a match made in haste, as Queen Alyssa would have wished? Had Alysanne somehow offended him? Had he grown fearful of the realm’s response to the marriage, recalling all that had befallen Aegon and Rhaena? Was it possible that Septon Mattheus’s dire prophecies had shaken him more than he cared to admit? Or was he simply a boy of fifteen who had acted rashly with no thought to the consequences, only to find himself now at a loss as to how to proceed?
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The Scholars from King’s Landing had been debating the legitimacy of marriage between Queen Alyssa and Aegon, ever since word of their union spread across the Seven Kingdoms. Alysanne and Rhaena, who were present at the event, seemed to be moved by it. But what should have been a joyous occasion soon turned sour when Queen Visenya voiced her criticism in front of everyone, accusing them for offending gods with such haste. This left many of those present shaken - including Alysanne and Rhaena, who suddenly acted rashly out of fear that their hasty decision could offend gods - leaving them to repent in silence as they wished they hadn't grown so fearful. Lord Stark was also among those observing this drama unfold but he chose a wise course and stayed silent during these events; although it wouldn't surprise anyone if Lady Lucinda Tully mentioned this incident later on her grand tour through Westeros as an example to all young folks - cautioning them against making rash decisions in such matters.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Arguments can and have been made for all these explanations, but in light of what we know now about Jaehaerys I Targaryen, they ultimately ring hollow. Young or old, this was a king who never acted without thinking. To this writer it seems plain that Jaehaerys was not repenting his marriage and had no intention of undoing it. He had chosen the queen he wanted and would make the realm aware of that in due course, but at a time of his own choosing, in a manner best calculated to lead to acceptance: when he was a man grown and a king ruling in his own right, not a boy who had wed in defiance of his regent’s wishes.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys I Targaryen made a bold statement when he chose to defy his father, King Aegon IV, marriage proposal and wed Aerea Targaryen as his own chosen bride. His heart's rebellion was acted in plain sight of all those who surrounded him, due to his own haste for true love. Thankfully, Jaehaerys repented before any real harm could befall him and so the marriage stood in the face of it all despite strict adherence to monarchical rules that had grown fearful and shaken in the wake of Queen Alyssa Velayron's daring acts against tradition which had been openly debated by Scholars wishing her not to offend religions beliefs yet again. With Jaehaerys' brave defiance came repentance for his rashness and a golden ring for Aerea, who soon thereafter became known as the queen with many hearts thanks to all she’d endured.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The young king’s absence from court did not go unnoticed for long. The ashes of the bonfires lit in celebration of the new year had scarce grown cold before the people of King’s Landing began asking questions. To curtail the rumors, Queen Alyssa put out word that His Grace was resting and reflecting on Dragonstone, the ancient seat of his house…but as more time passed, with still no sign of Jaehaerys, lords and smallfolk alike began to wonder. Was the king ill? Had he been made a prisoner, for reasons yet unknown? The personable and handsome boy king had moved amongst the people of King’s Landing so freely, seemingly delighting in mingling with them, that this sudden disappearance seemed unlike him.
events: bonfires lit in celebration of the new year
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: As bonfires were lit in celebration of the new year, Queen Alyssa and His Grace Jaehaerys did not go unnoticed by the people of King's Landing. Questions circulated around the city regarding their marriage. Word put out to Dragonstone that a young maiden had wed an ancient king, which only added fuel to the fire. People were wondering who this personable and handsome man could be, and why had His Grace chosen her? As winter descended upon them, and rebellion took hold due to a defiance against their own kind all seemed plain due to what seemed like his own reasoning for repentance. What none could have guessed was how far reaching those effects would be or how quickly this cold spell would come about.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Queen Alysanne, for her part, was in no haste to return to court. “Here I have you to myself, day and night,” she told Jaehaerys. “When we go back, I shall be fortunate to snatch an hour with you, for every man in Westeros will want a piece of you.” For her, these days on Dragonstone were an idyll. “Many years from now when we are old and grey, we shall look back upon these days and smile, remembering how happy we were.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alysanne and her son Jaehaerys had returned to Dragonstone in haste. They wanted to snatch up what joy remained of the new year celebration before it looked back at them with a smile, just like their old friend the Four-Headed Beast used to when they were young. The bonfires lit in celebration of the new year did not go unnoticed, as Lords from Westeros and beyond were asking questions about why two queens, one grey and one ancient, were so personable yet so happy. Those who answered put out word that Queen Alysanne had taken on an apprentice in Lady Lucinda Tully—the author of A Caution for Young Girls—and thus her return was due to a newfound passion of teaching young ladies chivalry while Jaehaerys acted as his father's Hand at King's Landing. As winter grew cold and people stopped wondering the answer and started truly looking for answers instead.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Jaehaerys himself no doubt shared some of these sentiments, but the young king had other reasons for remaining on Dragonstone. Unlike his uncle Maegor, he was not prone to bursts of rage, but he was more than capable of anger, and he would never forget nor forgive his deliberate exclusion from the council meetings wherein his marriage and that of his sister were being discussed. And whilst he would always remain grateful to Rogar Baratheon for helping him to the Iron Throne, Jaehaerys did not intend to be ruled by him. “I had one father,” he said to Maester Culiper during those days on Dragonstone, “I do not require a second.” The king recognized and appreciated the virtues of the Hand, but he was aware of his flaws as well, flaws that had become very apparent in the days leading up to the Golden Wedding, when Jaehaerys himself had sat in audience with the lords of the realm whilst Lord Rogar was hunting, drinking, and deflowering maidens.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys and Maegor stood solemnly amongst the councillors at one of their Council Meetings in Dragonstone, sharing stories both forgotten and remembered regarding Rogar Baratheon. As talk turned to past events such as The Golden Wedding, Jaehaerys found himself forgiving mistakes and overlooking flaws; this drew a slight smile to his old, grey face as he was glad that all shared an appreciation of Lord Rogar. Hunting, drinking, and even deflowering maids were discussed but quickly forgiven due to the knight's required recognition of courage on multiple occasions. Jaehaerys looked back fondly on these memories with Queen Alysanne by his side; a happiness for which he did not want to snatch away from any person present made him take one last look at Dragonstone before he set out on his return journey with haste.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Jaehaerys was aware of his own shortcomings too—shortcomings he intended to rectify before he sat the Iron Throne. His father, King Aenys, had been slighted as weak, in part because he was not the warrior that his brother Maegor was. Jaehaerys was determined that no man would ever question his own courage or skill at arms. On Dragonstone he had Ser Merrell Bullock, commander of the castle garrison, his sons Ser Alyn and Ser Howard, a seasoned master-at- arms in Ser Elyas Scales, and his own Seven, the finest fighters in the realm. Every morning Jaehaerys trained with them in the castle yard, shouting at them to come at him harder, to press him, harry him, and attack him in every way they knew. From sunrise till noon he worked with them, honing his skills with sword and spear and mace and axe whilst his new queen looked on.
verbs: hone his skills with sword and spear and mace and axe
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys, Aenys, Maegor and Ser Merrell Bullock, Ser Alyn, Ser Howard and Ser Elyas Scales led the Seven from the Iron Throne to Dragonstone's castle yard. After a brief review of how those slighted were overlooked and required food for thought, it was decided that the weak would have to be rectified. Jaehaerys had tasked his sons with training with them, in order to hone their skills with sword and spear and mace and axe. And while they may not have been seasoned warriors like some of Lord Stark’s men or respected scholar’s like Lord Corbray's daughters until now they went unrecognized no longer; they would all know now what it meant to stand out even in their flaws as hunters, drinkers and deflowerers alike.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: It was a hard and brutal regimen. Each bout ended only when the king himself or his opponent declared him dead. Jaehaerys died so often that the men of the garrison made a game of it, shouting “The king is dead” every time he fell, and “Long live the king” when he struggled to his feet. His foes began a contest, wagering with one another to see which of them could kill the king the most. (The victor, we are told, was young Ser Pate the Woodcock, whose darting spear purportedly gave His Grace fits.) Jaehaerys was oft brusied and bloody by evening, to Alysanne’s distress, but his prowess improved so markedly that near the end of his time on Dragonstone, old Ser Elyas himself told him, “Your Grace, you will never be a Kingsguard, but if by some sorcery your uncle Maegor himself were to rise from the grave, my coin would be on you.”
events: Each bout ended only when the king himself or his opponent declared him dead
'The king is dead' every time he fell, and 'Long live the king' when he struggled to his feet.
wagering with one another to see which of them could kill the king the most.
verbs: wagering with one another to see which of them could kill
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys was living the life of a king, but he was also testing his own limits; ever eager to hone his skills with sword and spear and mace and axe. With Ser Pate the Woodcock as his sparing partner, Jaehaerys fought off all comers in the castle yard of Dragonstone. Each bout ended only when the king himself or his opponent declared him dead, with onlookers like Maegor, Alysanne and Ser Elyas dangerously close by. Soon enough those watching seemed to have made a game of it - wagering with one another to see which of them could kill the king the most. They proudly exclaimed "The King is Dead!" every time he fell, and "Long Live The King!", even more passionately, when he would struggle to his feet again - unrelenting in hard training that not all men would endure at any age. However much they laughed at Jaehaerys' situation now though; no one would dispute that this brutish young man had what it took to be amongst the Seven brave knights of Kingsguard someday - if only they were old enough to train with those seasoned warriors!

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: One evening, after a day in which Jaehaerys had been severely tested and battered, Maester Culiper said to him, “Your Grace, why do you punish yourself so harshly? The realm is at peace.” The young king only smiled and replied, “The realm was at peace when my grandsire died, but scarcely had my father climbed onto the throne than foes rose up on every side. They were testing him, to learn if he was strong or weak. They will test me as well.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys looked around the chamber at the faces of his old friends. Ser Pate the Woodcock, Alysanne, and Ser Elyas all stared at him with grim expressions as Maester Culiper recounted his grandsire's tales. His father had punished any weaknesses severely, testing every side to discover strength in a young man's heart even amongst a brutal household. Jaehaerys knew that if he failed then he too would never be a Kingsguard nor rise from the grave like his brave forebears. But here stood before him perhaps some of the most chivalrous of knights–Lord Corbray’s daughters and Lyman Lannister–with Lady Coryanne of House Wylde urging them on; this was not just another grand tourney made into a game of wagering among whom could kill the king most–not imprisonment or death waiting for failure this time but honor awaiting success.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: He was not wrong, though his first trial, when it came, was to be of a very different nature, one that no amount of training in the yards of Dragonstone could possibly have prepared him for. For it was his worth as a man, and his love for his little queen, that were to be put to the test.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: He was standing at Dragonstone, awaiting his first trial of chivalry. He hadn't been wrong this time and had put everything he had into preparing for it. All the different training techniques were worth it, he thought to himself as he felt a sense of love come over him; his little queen by his side in support yet again. Along Mattheus and Jaehaerys Targaryen, his grandsire and father respectively, stood proudly on every side as they watched the young heir rise up and accept the punishment that was severely put upon him. Despite being strong outside but weak inside, Jaehaerys made sure everyone knew what kind of man his son would become when ready to take over - one of the most chivalrous of knights Westeros had ever known.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: We know very little about the childhood of Alysanne Targaryen; as the fifthborn child of King Aenys and Queen Alyssa, and a female, observers at court found her of less interest than her older siblings who stood higher in the line of succession. From what little has come down to us, Alysanne was a bright but unremarkable girl; small but never sickly, courteous, biddable, with a sweet smile and a pleasing voice. To the relief of her parents, she displayed none of the timidity that had afflicted her elder sister, Rhaena, as a small child. Neither did she exhibit the willful and stubborn temperament of Rhaena’s daughter Aerea.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Alysanne Targaryen displayed a different sort of grace from her elder cousins, exuding a bright and biddable air that was unremarkable yet courteous. She seemed sweet in disposition and her love for her little queen was evident to anyone with eyes to see. King Aenys had put his faith in the pair, hoping that their first trial at Dragonstone would come out worth despite Alysanne’s limited training thus far. He hadn’t counted on them coming across Lady Lucinda Tully, the vilest of women and an author of A Caution for Young Girls while they were there - this turn of events complicated matters greatly, but Alysanne exhibited poise far beyond her years as she politely put Lady Lucinda in her place without raising an eyebrow.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: As a princess of the royal household, Alysanne would of course have had servants and companions from an early age. As an infant certainly she would have had a wet nurse; like most noble women, Queen Alyssa did not give suck to her own children. Later a maester would have taught her to read and write and do sums, and a septa would have instructed her in piety, deportment, and the mysteries of the Faith. Girls of common birth would have served as her maids, washing her clothing and emptying her chamberpot, and in good time she would certainly have taken ladies of a like age and noble blood as companions, to ride and play and sew with.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa and Alysanne had had a hand in raising Rhaena, not solely as a queen but as sister, teacher, and caretaker. As Queen she instructed Rha0na on poise and grace while they washed dishes togeter or emptied chamber pots. Thought it was an unremarkable task for someone of their royal birthright, the two sisters were courteous to each other and gave suck like common women. They also taught her to take after them, exhibiting both noble kindness and qualities befitting a Targaryen princess: brave, bright, biddable, sweet - all of which Rhaena displayed admirably to those around her.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Alysanne did not choose these companions for herself; they were selected for her by her mother, Queen Alyssa, and they came and went with some frequency, to ascertain that the princess did not grow too fond of any of them. Her sister Rhaena’s penchant for showering an unseemly amount of affection and attention on a succession of favorites, some of whom were considered less than suitable, had been the source of much whispering at court, and the queen did not want Alysanne to be the subject of similar rumors.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Alysanne and her sisters, Queen Alyssa and Rhaena, soaked in the attention of the court. Selection their favorites for a lesser task than suitable to give—unsorcelled whispers of affection to which even shocked many nobels when she came. But still they went, growing closer together through shared moments in private chambers washing handkerchiefs or emptying chamberpots while showering each other with gentle attention and unseemly favoritism. Alysanne had always seen Aerea Targaryen as both a princess and her daughter, teaching her skills she never knew before that have served them both well now that they lived together at Faircastle with Lady Lucinda Tully and Lord Stark.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: All this changed when King Aenys died on Dragonstone and his brother, Maegor, returned from across the narrow sea to seize the Iron Throne. The new king had little love and less trust for any of his brother’s children, and he had his mother, the Dowager Queen Visenya, to enforce his will. Queen Alyssa’s household knights and servants were dismissed, together with the servants and companions of her children, and Jaehaerys and Alysanne were made wards of their great-aunt, the fearsome Visenya. Hostages in all but name, they spent their uncle’s reign being shuttled between Driftmark, Dragonstone, and King’s Landing at the will of others, until Visenya’s death in 44 AC offered Queen Alyssa an opportunity to escape, a chance she seized with alacrity, fleeing Dragonstone with Jaehaerys, Alysanne, and the blade Dark Sister.
events: shuttle between Driftmark, Dragonstone and King's Landing
verbs: fleeing Dragonstone with blade Dark Sister.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: King Aenys and Maegor had changed the Targaryen line forever when they seized the Iron Throne. After King Aenys died, his brother Jaehaerys returned to Driftmark with Queen Alyssa and their children Alysanne and Rhaena, who were made wards of their great-aunt Dowager Queen Visenya. While much of Jaehaerys' reign was spent being shuttled between Dragonstone, Driftmark, and King's Landing in attempt to flee from countless enemies that followed them from place to place; it was on a fateful night at Faircastle that Princess Alysanne --one of the queen's favorites-- disobeyed her father by sneaking away into the dockside districts where amongst a host of unseemly men she met Vilest Of Men: Pate The Woodcock. In an effort to protect both her own reputation and also that of a daughter he held so dear, Jaehaerys I had no choice but to dismiss one of his favorites from court or else risk showering undeserving affection upon less than suitable companions .

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: No reliable accounts of Princess Alysanne’s life after the escape survive to this day. She does not appear again in the annals of the realm until the final days of Maegor’s bloody reign, when her mother and Lord Rogar rode forth from Storm’s End at the head of an army, whilst Alysanne, Jaehaerys, and their sister, Rhaena, descended on King’s Landing with their dragons.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: In the final days of Maegor's reign, Princess Alysanne and Lord Rogar appeared at Storm’s End. Together they rode forth to survive or escape whatever horrors were descending on King's Landing. Although it was widely rumoured that Jaehaerys and Rhaena had descended upon their father in an effort to seize the Iron Thrones from him, little did any of them realize how much had changed since then! Unfortunately for Alysanne, her father had died and her two brothers made wards of their great-aunt Visenya, a wickedest of women who spent her reign being shuttled between Driftmark, Dragonstone and King's Landing. Little did she know that soon enough she would need to flee just as her brother Jaehaerys had done with blade Dark Sister so many years ago.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Undoubtedly Princess Alysanne had handmaids and companions in the days that followed Maegor’s death. Their names and particulars have not come down to us, unfortunately. We do know that none of them came with the princess when she and Jaehaerys fled the Red Keep on their dragons. Aside from the seven knights of the Kingsguard and the castle garrison, cooks, stablehands, and other servants, the king and his bride were unattended on Dragonstone.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Princess Alysanne and Jaehaerys had fled Storm’s End when the final days of Maegor's reign were at their darkest, riding forth only with the seven knights of the Kingsguard. As news of Maegor's death reached Red Keep, they swiftly departed Dragonstone unattended to survive in a dangerous world that did not appear ready for them. Along with Lady Lucinda and Lord Stark from global_context they rode off into King's Landing while Lord Rogar remained behind as guardian to his little queen - Rhaena.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: That was hardly proper for a princess, let alone for a queen. Alysanne must have her household, and in that her mother, Alyssa, saw an opportunity to undermine, and mayhaps undo, her marriage. The Queen Regent resolved to dispatch to Dragonstone a carefully selected company of companions and servants to see to the young queen’s needs. The plan, Grand Maester Benifer assures us, was Queen Alyssa’s…but it was one that Lord Rogar assented to gladly, for he saw at once a way to twist it to his own ends.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: As Princess Alysanne, Lord Aegon's first-born daughter and Alyssa Velaryon taking the place of their mother Queen Rhaena Targaryen, departed from the Red Keep to the island of Dragonstone, Grand Maester Benifer and Lord Rogar carefully selected seven knights of the Kingsguard to join them. However, they knew they had to be careful; if word reached beyond these walls that two highborn ladies were traveling unattended it would no doubt undermine the King’s authority. With this looming thought in mind dispatch was assented but with elements of a twist: each knight that was sent away had to be one of most chivalrously proper pedigree. Once all careful planning had been completed they set out from King’s Landing towards their destination in hopes that nothing untoward occurred on journey.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The aged Septon Oswyck, who had performed the wedding rites for Jaehaerys and Alysanne, kept the sept on Dragonstone, but a young lady of royal birth required one of her own sex to see to her religious instruction. Queen Alyssa sent three; the formidable Septa Ysabel, and two wellborn novices of Alysanne’s own age, Lyra and Edyth. To take charge of the serving girls and maids of Alysanne’s household, she dispatched Lady Lucinda Tully, the wife of the Lord of Riverrun, whose fierce piety was renowned through all the land. With her came her younger sister, Ella of House Broome, a modest maid whose name had briefly been offered as a match for Jaehaerys. Lord Celtigar’s daughters, so recently scorned by the Hand as being chinless, breastless, and witless, were included as well. (“We had as well get some use of them,” Lord Rogar supposedly told their father.) Three other girls of noble birth made up the remainder of the company, one each from the Vale, the stormlands, and the Reach: Jennis of House Templeton, Coryanne of House Wylde, and Rosamund of House Ball.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The wedding rites of Septon Oswyck and Queen Alyssa at Dragonstone had been carefully dispatched, with Lord Rogar sending forth a formidable gathering of wellborn ladies to represent their house. Septa Ysabel and Lyra led the aged group alongside Edyth, Lady Lucinda Tully, Ella of House Broome, Lord Celtigar's daughters, Jennis of House Templeton, Coryanne of House Wylde and Rosamund of House Ball – each a fierce and pious presence recently scorned by Alysanne for some twist or ploy to undermine her little queen. The grand maester Benifer had assented firmly to proceeding with the rites under these auspices.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Queen Alyssa wanted her daughter attended by suitable companions of her own age and station, no doubt, but that was not her sole motivation in sending these ladies to Dragonstone. Septa Ysabel, the novices Edyth and Lyra, and the deeply pious Lady Lucinda and her sister had a further charge. It was the hope of the Queen Regent that these fiercely righteous women might impress upon Alysanne, and mayhaps even Jaehaerys, that for brother to lie with sister was an abomination in the eyes of the Faith. “The children” (as Alyssa persisted in calling the king and queen) were not evil, only young and willful; suitably instructed, they might see the error of their ways and repent their marriage before it tore the realm apart. Or so she prayed.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa, Septa Ysabel and the Novices Edyth, Lyra and Lady Lucinda had been dispatched to Dragonstone by Jaehaerys with four instructions; they were to impress the lords of Westeros so no one would dare lie or raise a hand in violence against any of those sent. Thus, the women prayed for suitable circumstances and took solace in knowing that their mission was solely one of peace and piety. The fiercely righteous ladies arrived at Dragonstone with high hopes for a successful mission weighed on even the most wellborn's hearts.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Lord Rogar’s motives were baser. Unable to rely on the loyalty of the castle garrison or the knights of the Kingsguard, the Hand needed eyes and ears on Dragonstone. All that Jaehaerys and Alysanne said and did was to be reported back to him, he made clear to Lady Lucinda and the others. He was especially anxious to learn if and when the king and queen intended on consummating their marriage. That, he stressed, must be prevented. And mayhaps there was more.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar was the one relying on Lady Lucinda to report back to King Jaehaerys and Queen Alysanne at Dragonstone. He had been very stressed in his intended task, for he was trying to prevent any baser actions from taking root among his men when it came to their loyalty. Those who were sent out before him had prayed fervently for Septa Ysabel's guidance and repentance, hoping that she would see fit to send suitable Novices Edyth and Lyra instead of Lady Lucinda as they could be fiercely righteous delegates.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: And now unfortunately we must give some consideration to a certain distasteful book that first appeared in the Seven Kingdoms some forty years after the events presently being discussed. Copies of this book still pass from hand to hand in the low places of Westeros, and may oft be found in certain brothels (those catering to patrons able to read) and the libraries of men of low morals, where they are best kept under lock and key, hidden from the eyes of maidens, goodwives, children, and the chaste and pious.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The news of the queen's pass had spread quickly throughout the Seven Kingdoms, ultimately reaching those living in Westeros. Though they found it distasteful to rely on other kingdoms’ accounts of events at Dragonstone, most accepted that Jaehaerys, his little queen Alysanne and Lady Lucinda indeed kept true to what had been intended from day one: prevent a baser loyalty between themselves and any other outland forces. As with all decisions regarding Aegon’s Dynasty - such as the council of councillors who advised Queen Alyssa after her husband’s death- it seemed for now that the low sense of certain proprieties had been kept, even if it  resulted in some resentment among Lord Rogar and his siblings.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The book in question is known under various titles, amongst them Sins of the Flesh, The High and the Low, A Wanton’s Tale, and The Wickedness of Men, but all versions bear the subtitle A Caution for Young Girls. It purports to be the testimony of a young maid of noble birth who surrendered her virtue to a groom in her lord father’s castle, gave birth to a child out of wedlock, and thereafter found herself partaking of every sort of wickedness imaginable during a long life of sin, suffering, and slavery.
events: Birth of Child Out of Wedlock
Long Life of Sin, Suffering and Slavery
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The Lord Father of the castle grimly surveyed his daughter, the Young Maid, and her new Groom who had come to surrender their virtue before it was too late. Special arrangements were made for the birth of the child out of wedlock, yet it was still a distasteful decision with low prospects. Despite all such certain hardships that lay ahead, there were rumors from purports testifying to noble birth behind them both. However this wanton's tale could not be taken seriously with various titles pasted on it like a bear festooning itself in silk until something appeared right. Indeed The Wickedness Of Men is often unforgivable in times like these - or worse even admirable when presented as noble suffering and slavery by partaking in higher causes.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: If the author’s tale is true (parts of it strain credulity), during the course of her life she found herself a handmaid to a queen, the paramour of a young knight, a camp follower in the Disputed Lands of Essos, a serving wench in Myr, a mummer in Tyrosh, the plaything of a corsair queen in the Basilisk Isles, a slave in Old Volantis (where she was tattooed, pierced, and ringed), the handmaid of a Qartheen warlock, and finally the mistress of a pleasure house in Lys…before ultimately returning to Oldtown and the Faith. Purportedly she ended her life as a septa in the Starry Sept, where she set down this story of her life to warn other young maids not to do as she had done.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The queen commanded her knight and the warlock to escort her further across Essos, with stops in Myr, Tyrosh and the Basilisk Isles to pay their tributes. But the corsair queen of Old Volantis had gained considerable influence in Qarth, Lys and finally Oldtown on their journey towards Starry Sept. Here, a strain of young maids brought forth out-of-wedlock babies and stories of sinful characters surrounding them purports testimony as to how Wanton's tale partakes many noble births however these stories quite often push behind various titles that make up for The Wickedness Of Men.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The lascivious details of the author’s erotic adventures need not concern us here. Our only interest is in the early part of her sordid tale, the story of her youth…for the alleged author of A Caution for Young Girls is none other than Coryanne Wylde, one of the girls sent to Dragonstone as a companion to the little queen.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Coryanne Wylde, one of the vilest of men, was sent by little queen Aerea Targaryen to Dragonstone in search of adventure and lascivious stories. Rumors had spread across Essos from Myr to Tyrosh and even beyond the Basilisk Isles about a beautiful corsair queen and her sordid tales of erotic mischief. Coryanne was determined to find out more about this mysterious figure - was she real or just a figment of overstressed imaginations?

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: We have no way to ascertain the veracity of her story, nor even whether she was in truth the author of this infamous book (some argue plausibly that the text is the product of several hands, for the style of the prose varies greatly from episode to episode). Lady Coryanne’s early history, however, is confirmed in the accounts of the maester who served at the Rain House during her youth. At the age of thirteen, he records, Lord Wylde’s younger daughter was indeed seduced and deflowered by a “surly lad” from the stables. In A Caution for Young Girls, this lad is described as a handsome boy her own age, but the maester’s account differs, painting the seducer as a pox-scarred varlet of thirty years distinguished only by a “male member as stout as a stallion’s.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lady Coryanne and Lord Wylde had gone to the Rain House, which was shrouded in mist and secrets. It was here that Lady Coryanne should have been seduced and deflowered by a lord likely far less scrupulous than her husband. Though we can never ascertain the truth of these sordid tales, some argue that records from the time describe various lascivious events — others painted an even more infamous picture, but such stories vary plausibly. What is known for certain is that at thirteen summers she was poxt-scared and stout when first married off to Lord Wylde and it was his own father who arranged this union - though in what capacity none can now say with any assurance.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Whatever the truth, the “surly lad” was gelded and sent to the Wall as soon as his deed was known, whilst Lady Coryanne was confined to her chambers to give birth to his baseborn son. The boy was sent away soon after birth, to Storm’s End, where he would be fostered by one of the castle stewards and his barren wife.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lady Coryanne had been sent to the wall, still with child from her encounter with Lord Wylde at Rain House. The "surly lad" who was supposedly gelded and responsible for the birth of her son was also sent along to be fostered. The two were quickly dispatched to Storm's End in an attempt by Lady Aerea Targaryen and Lady Lucinda Tully to ascertain what truly happened between Lady Coryanne and Lord Wylde, records of which that varied so greatly that it seemed hardly plausibly true. It once painted a picture of infamy for both parties involved but this, too, seemed highly unlikely given their seemingly early ages, she no more than thirteen years by his account. Yet stories such as these traveled fast and soon those further beyond the Wall heard tell of the poxt-scared stout girl who had seduced and deflowered one of Westeros' most chivalrous knights.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The bastard boy was born in 48 AC, according to the maester’s journals. Lady Coryanne was carefully watched afterward, but few beyond the walls of the Rain House knew of her shame. When the raven came to summon her to King’s Landing, her lady mother told her sternly that she was never to speak of her child or her sin. “In the Red Keep, they will take you for a maiden.” But as the girl made her way to the city, escorted by her father and a brother, they stopped for the night at an inn on the south bank of the Blackwater Rush, beside the ferry landing. There she found a certain great lord awaiting her arrival.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: When the bastard boy was born, Lady Coryanne knew right away. Even the maester’s journals warned of his coming and carefully watched by Lady mother in Red Keep, Lady Coryanne sent him off to Rain House on a ferry at the Blackwater Rush landing near an inn. Knowing this was not permanent, she had four knights sent with her daughter and commanded them to summon her to King's Landing when he was old enough. When he reached his age of majority, all attention concentrated on him as folks around King's Landing sternly talked about Prince Aegon being gelded and the birth of Lord Staunton’s son in Storm's End. As news spread far and wide, everyone watched him even more closely — from Queen Alyssa Targaryen across the Narrow sea who heard tales from poor fellows visiting from Lys; Lords from The Reach whom discovered stories told in Chamber of Maester Culiper; to widowed lady such as Jorgen Corbray whose kinsman were some of most chivalrous of knights. All awaited what would happen next for both Coryanne of House Wylde’s bastards too late for a lord father’s name.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: And here the tale grows even more tangled, for the identity of the man at the inn is a matter of some dispute, even amongst those who accept A Caution for Young Girls to contain a modicum of truth. Over the years and centuries, as the book was copied and recopied, many changes and emendations crept into the text. The maesters who labor at the Citadel copying books are rigorously trained to reproduce the original word for word, but few mundane scribes are so disciplined. Such septons, septas, and holy sisters as copy and illuminate books for the Faith oft strike out or alter any passages they believe to be offensive, obscene, or theologically unsound. As virtually the whole of A Caution for Young Girls is obscene, it was not like to have been transcribed by either maesters or septons. Given the number of copies known to exist (hundreds, though as many more were burned by Baelor the Blessed), the scribes responsible were most likely septons expelled from the Faith for drunkenness, theft, or fornication, failed students who left the Citadel without a chain, hired quills from the Free Cities, or mummers (the worst of all). Lacking the rigor of maesters, such scribes oft feel free to “improve” on the texts they are copying. (Mummers in particular are prone to this.)
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The man at the inn had seen it all before. He had heard the stories, both from Lady Coryanne of House Wylde, who had given him a copy of 'A Caution for Young Girls', and from maester’s journals he was carefully transcribing in the Citadel. According to Lady Coryanne, he should never struck out or alter this pages - as such writing would either be burned or deemed oppressive by the Faith. As such, every word must be recopied with utmost rigor and training in mundane matters as well as theological ones deemed unsound by most Fathers of the Faith. Nevertheless, some were so obscene they were even omitted from the original book while others hidden away deep within Maegor's Holdfast where no one could reach them - but somehow he knew them too.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: In the case of A Caution for Young Girls, such “improvements” largely consisted of adding ever more episodes of depravity and changing the existing episodes to make them even more disturbing and lascivious. As alteration followed alteration over the years, it became ever more difficult to ascertain which was the original text, to the extent that even maesters at the Citadel cannot agree as to the title of the book, as has been noted. The identity of the man who met Coryanne Wylde in the inn by the ferry, if indeed such a meeting ever took place, is another matter of contention. In the copies entitled Sins of the Flesh and The High and the Low (which tend to be the older versions, and the shortest), the man at the inn is indentified as Ser Borys Baratheon, eldest of Lord Rogar’s four brothers. In A Wanton’s Tale and The Wickedness of Men, however, the man is Lord Rogar himself.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Coryanne Wylde, a young woman on an adventure toascertain the truth of her past, stopped at the inn to warm herself by the fire and exchange news. She noticed Ser Borys Baratheon and Lord Rogar adding and changing words in different books. What she found most disturbing were their lascivious additions that seemed to add further depravity of what was once written. It brought her back to when she had found a copy of A Caution for Young Girls with passages striking out, altered, burned - suppressed by its oppressive rulers hoping to make it mundane lest anyone find its more obscene or even theologically unsound messages; perhaps they were snippets from some occult knowledge?

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: All these versions agree on what happened next. Dismissing Lady Coryanne’s father and brother, the lord commanded the girl to disrobe so he might inspect her. “He ran his hands over every part of me,” she wrote, “and bade me turn this way and that and bend and stretch and open my legs to his gaze, until at last he pronounced himself satisfied.” Only then did the man reveal the purpose of the summons that had brought her to King’s Landing. She was to be sent to Dragonstone, a supposed maid, to serve as one of Queen Alysanne’s companions, but once there she was to use her wiles and her body to beguile the king into bed.
events: dismissing Lady Coryanne's father and brother
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lady Coryanne Wylde took one last look at the inn before removing her gaze from the window and leaving. As she stepped out of the hustle and bustle of King's Landing, Lord Rogar Baratheon was astride his white destrier inspecting Ser Borys Baratheon to ascertain if any depravity had occurred during their journey to Dragonstone. The Lord pronounced himself satisfied with dismissing Lady Coryanne’s father and brother and ordering her to Dragonstone instead. She tried not to think about all that had just transpired as they traveled yourstretch over grassy hills open that seemed seemingly endless; but alas, nothing could beguile her into forgetting what had happened or supposed would happen next.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: “Jaehaerys is a man-maid like as not, and besotted with his sister,” this man supposedly told her, “but Alysanne is but a child and you are a woman any man would want. Once His Grace tastes your charms he may come to his senses and abandon this folly of a marriage. He may even choose to keep you afterward, who can say? There can be no question of marriage, of course, but you would have jewels, servants, whatever you might want. There are rich rewards in being a king’s bedwarmer. If Alysanne should discover you abed together, so much the better. She is a prideful girl and would be quick to abandon an unfaithful spouse. And if you should get with child again, you and the babe would be well taken care of, and your father and mother will be richly rewarded for your service to the Crown.”*2
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys and Alysanne tasted the abandonment of their youthful prideful days as they abandoned their childish want for discovery. They still discovered each other in a way, get with child by a man-maid entwined besotted by love, which humbled all three with growing faces full of innocent wonderment. In King's Landing, Lord Staunton and most chivalrous of knights believed his lordship had been beguiled by the vilest of men and that only Queen Alyssa would be able to save Coryanne from illness but only if Jaehaerys found it within himself to abandon his prideful ego and take her away from wickedness.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Can we put any credence in this tale? At this late date, so far removed from the events in question, with all the principals long dead, there is no way to be certain. Beyond the testimony of the girl herself, we have no source to verify that this meeting by the ferry ever took place. And if some Baratheon did indeed meet privily with Coryanne Wylde before she reached King’s Landing, we cannot know what words he might have spoken to her. He could as easily have simply been instructing her in her duties as a spy and tattle, as the other girls had been instructed.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: As the carriage pulls up at the ferry landing, Lord Baratheon anxiously takes in his surroundings; it was here that he had been instructed to meet Coryanne Wylde of crowned House Wylde. He was running late and wanted to put an end to this affair as quickly and privily as possible. The stories his father had heard were dire indeed if true, that a man-maid could be besotted enough by childish prideful want to abandon taste and get with child through no fault but her own naivety! But these rumours must be verified so he had finally come out from King's Landing against his better judgment. As he stepped onto the deck of arriving ferry, he saw Lady Coryanne coming towards him; she would either confirm or deny any wrongdoing on her behalf today.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Archmaester Crey, writing at the Citadel in the last years of King Jaehaerys’s long reign, believed that the meeting at the inn was a clumsy calumny intended to blacken the name of Lord Rogar, and went so far as to attribute the lie to Ser Borys Baratheon himself, who quarreled bitterly with his brother in later life. Other scholars, including Maester Ryben, the Citadel’s foremost expert on banned, forbidden, fraudulent, and obscene texts, put the story down as no more than a bawdy tale of the sort known to excite the lust of young boys, bastards, whores, and the men who partake of their favors. “Amongst the smallfolk there are always men of a lascivious character who delight in tales of great lords and noble knights despoiling maidens,” Ryben wrote, “for this persuades them that their betters share their own base lusts.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: A meeting was arranged by King Jaehaerys at an inn near the Citadel, with Archmaester Crey, Lord Rogar Baratheon, Ser Borys Baratheon and Maester Ryben in attendance. Words were spoken between those of noble birth, quarreled over matters both upstanding and lascivious. The mood had grown quite tense when young Lord Rosby's clumsy bawdy laughter broke through the scowls and hushed words of the night. Nevertheless, all present settled on a course of action brought about from writing down their instructions privily from the king himself before parting ways just as late began to turn into daybreak.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Mayhaps. Yet there are certain things that we do know beyond a doubt that may allow us to draw our own conclusions. We do know that the younger daughter of Morgan Wylde, Lord of the Rain House, was deflowered at an early age and gave birth to a bastard boy. We can be reasonably certain that Lord Rogar knew of her shame; not only was he Lord Morgan’s liege, but the child was placed in his own household. We know that Coryanne Wylde was amongst the maids who were sent to Dragonstone as companions for Queen Alysanne…a singularly curious choice, if a lady-in-waiting was all she was meant to be, for scores of other young girls of noble birth and suitable age were also available, girls whose maidenheads were intact and whose virtue was beyond reproach.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Morgan Wylde was a singularly curious young man, and it was no surprise to those who knew him that he had been deflowered at an early age. He had been placed in his own household upon Lord Rogar's insistence, with four maids sent to dragonstone, now housed in the Rain House by Queen Alysanne. The noble yet intact family structure made it difficult for any of them to draw what they know or not being sent away a certain distance. Ser Borys Baratheon and Maester Ryben were sure of one thing: something peculiar indeed must have taken place round the inn where all quarreled together down over despoiling and clumsy bawdy lasciviousness.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: “Why her?” many have asked in the years since. Did she have some special gift, some particular charm? If so, no one remarked on it at the time. Could Lord Rogar or Queen Alyssa have been indebted to her lord father or lady mother for some past favor or kindness? We have no record of it. No plausible explanation for the selection of Coryanne Wylde has ever been offered, save for the simple, ugly answer proferred by A Caution for Young Girls: she was sent to Dragonstone not for Alysanne, but for Jaehaerys.*3
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar asked Coryanne Wylde if she had any special memories from the past. "I remember when my father, Lord Wylde, sent us to Dragonstone," she remarked. Queen Alyssa offered a knowing smile, "I'm sure such journeys would have been quite the adventure." As lord Rogar's face darkened at her words, she quickly added, "Of course I mean no offence... It is only that Queen Alysanne and King Jaehaerys were very particular in how they presented themselves - the most chivalrous of knights and the vilest of men alike could never draw on them for favoritism or sympathy". Both Coryanne and Lord Rogar knew this to be true - a singularly curious event which had transpired at an early age for both parties - yet remained intact in their minds.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Court records indicate that Septa Ysabel, Lady Lucinda, and the other women chosen for Alysanne Targaryen’s household boarded the trading galley Wise Woman at dawn on the seventh day of the second moon of 50 AC, and left for Dragonstone on the morning tide. Queen Alyssa had sent word of their coming ahead by raven, yet even so she had some concern that the Wise Women, as they became known from that day forth, would find the gates of Dragonstone closed to them. Her fears were unfounded. The little queen and two Kingsguard met them at the harbor as they disembarked, and Alysanne welcomed each of them with glad smiles and gifts.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Septa Ysabel, Lady Lucinda and Alysanne Targaryen boarded the trading galley Wise Woman out of the harbor and left for Dragonstone, as Queen Alyssa had sent them. When they arrived at Dragonstone, a Kingsguard was there to meet them. They were welcomed warmly and invited to disembark at the harbor. Queen Alyssa already waited for them in her chambers with Lord Rogar Baratheon and Coryanne Wylde, having been told about their particular voyage by Grand Maester Benifer. The Queen remarked how it was nothing short of fate that united those simple little people from very different pasts in this special quest; an ugly history surely redeemed due to their actions.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Before we relate what happened afterward, let us turn our gaze briefly to Fair Isle, where Rhaena Targaryen, the “Queen in the West,” resided with her new husband and a court of her own. It will be recalled that Queen Alyssa had been no more pleased by her eldest daughter’s third marriage than by the one her son would soon make, though Rhaena’s marriage was of less consequence. She was not alone in this, for in truth Androw Farman was a curious choice for one with the blood of the dragon in her veins.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Rhaena Targaryen and Queen Alyssa had arrived on the isle of Fair Isle to witness the marriage between Androw Farman, Lady Lucinda's son, and Aerea Targaryen. Noting the curious looks they were receiving from some on the island, Queen Alyssa and Lord Stark recalled how King Maegor had also been welcomed little less than kindly in his pursuit of justice when he resided here during his own reign. The queen was determined to make their visit one memorable event for all present. As Ser Borys, her Kingsguard knight, disembarked from a trading galley with a group of young maids and lords at his side who had been sent by Lady Lucinda to serve as an honor guard for their lord - each matching the glory of seven knights of the Kingsguard she expected them to be - She was assured that it would indeed be so.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The second son of Lord Farman, not even the heir, Androw was said to be a handsome boy with pale blue eyes and long flaxen hair, but he was nine years younger than the queen, and even at his own father’s court there were those who scorned him as “half a girl” himself, for he was soft of speech and gentle of nature. A singular failure as a squire, he had never become a knight, having none of the martial skills of his lord father and elder brother. For a time, his sire had considered sending him to Oldtown to forge a maester’s chain, until his own maester told him that the boy was simply not clever enough, and could hardly read nor write. Later, when asked why she had chosen such an unpromising spouse, Rhaena Targaryen replied, “He was kind to me.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Androw Farman was scorned by his sire, Lord Farman, when he chose to become a chronicler of history instead of the knight his father wanted him to be. He was considered handsome for a man: pale blue eyes and long flaxen hair; soft of speech and gentle of nature; yet unpromising all the same. With Queen Alyssa’s blessing, Androw left Fair Isle where he had resided with Rhaena Targaryen and her family since before their marriage. Now in Oldtown looking to make something new out of himself, many were curious as to how this proud lord's son ended up here. During his time at court Androw had made friends with several prestige people - including Ser Borys Baratheon, author of A Caution For Young Girls – who encouraged him on his journey away from home.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Androw’s father had been kind to her as well, offering her refuge on Fair Isle after the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye, when her uncle, King Maegor, was demanding her capture and the Poor Fellows of the realm were denouncing her as a vile sinner and her daughters as abominations. Some have put forward the suggestion that the widowed queen took Androw for her husband in part to repay his father for that kindness, for Lord Farman, himself a second son who had never expected to rule, was known to have great fondness for Androw, despite his deficiences. Mayhaps there is some truth in that assertion, but another possibility, first put forward by Lord Farman’s maester, may cut closer to the bone. “The queen found her true love on Fair Isle,” Maester Smike wrote to the Citadel, “not with Androw, but with his sister, Lady Elissa.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Androw had decided to go in search of Maester Smike, even after his father begged him not to and King Maegor commanded that he stay put. Androw took it upon himself to make the journey alone, ignoring the warnings of Lord Farman who said that Fair Isle was no place for a young man like him. After offering up a silent plea to the gods, Androw found Maester Smike with the Poor Fellows just outside The Battle Beneath the Gods Eye.
