Taking a moment, he thanked them for taking such good care of the old maester before demanding what happened at Oldtown - denouncing any abominations his sire may have taken part in. Maester Smike began kindly explaining all that had taken place there; and while most found it vile, Androw offered words of encouragement and hope as more stories were revealed by global_context characters such as Lady Lucinda Tully and Ser Borys Baratheon—stories Androw would later write down in one of his maester’s journals.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Three years Androw’s elder, Elissa Farman shared her brother’s blue eyes and long flaxen hair, but elsewise she was as unlike him as a sibling could be. Sharp of wit and sharper of tongue, she loved horses, dogs, and hawks. She was a fine singer and a skilled archer, but her great love was sailing. The Wind Our Steed were the words of the Farmans of Fair Isle, who had sailed the western seas since the Dawn Age, and Lady Elissa embodied them. As a child, it was said that she spent more time at sea than upon the land. Her father’s crews used to laugh to see her climbing the rigging like a monkey. She sailed her own boat around Fair Isle at the age of four-and-ten, and by the time she was twenty she had voyaged as far north as Bear Island and as far south as the Arbor. Oftimes, to the horror of her lord father and lady mother, she spoke of her desire to take a ship beyond the western horizon to learn what strange and wondrous lands might lie on the far side of the Sunset Sea.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Androw and Elissa Farman shared a love unlike any other, though coming from different worlds of Fair Isle and Bear Island respectively. When Androw sailed for the Arbor in search for a new life, Elissa had been there, climbing along the dockside districts in pursuit of her own adventure. They spoke of their dreams to one another as if they were old friends; he with his long flaxen curls sharing stories of his sea voyages while she had sharp witsharper than most and fine skilled hands making anything out of nothing that could be found near or far. The love was magical enough for each wanted only to take the other by their side so they could together voyage across the Sunset Sea -- until it sadly came time that saying goodbye broke apart all plans made.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Lady Elissa had been twice betrothed, once at twelve and once at sixteen, but she had frightened off both boys, as her own father admitted ruefully. In Rhaena Targaryen, however, she found a like- minded companion, and in her the queen found a new confidant. Together with Alayne Royce and Samantha Stokeworth, two of Rhaena’s oldest friends, they became nigh inseparable, a court within the court that Ser Franklyn Farman, Lord Marq’s elder son, dubbed “the Four-Headed Beast.” Androw Farman, Rhaena’s new husband, was admitted to their circle from time to time, but never so often as to be taken for a fifth head. Most tellingly, Queen Rhaena never took him flying with her on the back of her dragon, Dreamfyre, an adventure she shared frequently with the ladies Elissa, Alayne, and Sam (in fairness, it is more than possible that the queen invited Androw to share the sky with her only to have him decline, for he was not of an adventurous disposition).
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lady Elissa and her betrothed, Rhaena Targaryen, took an immediate liking to one another. Despite the initial fright of being off Bear Island for the first time, Lady Elissa admitted that it was nice to find someone who shared her love for sailing and climbing. She said it made a refreshing change from having to constantly prove herself as both intelligent and skilled in a household largely dominated by men - especially when those around her were less than confidant in their abilities. Soon enough Androw Farman's sister and Ser Franklyn Farman's daughter found themselves inseparable like-minded friends, travelling with Lord Marq on his voyages across the Sunset Sea ruefully counting down until they once again set sail back to Fair Isle.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: It would be a mistake to regard Queen Rhaena’s time at Faircastle as an idyll, however. Not everyone welcomed her presence, by any means. Even here on this distant isle there were Poor Fellows, angered that Lord Marq, like his father before him, had given support and sanctuary to one they regarded as an enemy of the Faith. The continued presence of Dreamfyre on the island was also creating problems. Glimpsed every few years, a dragon was a wonder and a terror to behold, and it was true that some of the Fair Islanders took pride in having “a dragon of our own.” Others, however, were made anxious by the presence of the great beast, especially as she grew larger…and hungrier. Feeding a growing dragon is no small thing. And when it became known that Dreamfyre had produced a clutch of dragon eggs, a begging brother from the inland hills began to preach that Fair Isle would soon be overrun by dragons “devouring sheep and cows and men alike,” unless a dragonslayer came forth to put an end to the scourge. Lord Farman sent forth knights to seize the man and silence him, but not before thousands had heard his prophecies. Though the preacher died in the dungeons under Faircastle, his words lived on, filling the ignorant with fear wherever they were heard.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena welcomed Lord Marq and his finest knights to Faircastle with a great fanfare. Dreamfyre, the banner of House Farman, flew proudly in the morning breeze as they made their way through the inland hills, glimpsed between the white walls of Fair Isle along their journey. Generating an air of contentment with their presence and creating a sense of peace throughout the villages they passed by, Lord Marq preached of seizing upon that silence and maintaining that idyll distant from anxious cities which were quickly growing too familiar. He asked his fellow Lord to join him on this mission- one borne out of like-mindedness between himself and Lady Elissa who had been so suddenly frightened off seven months ago when he abruptly admitted Ser Franklyn Farman into its midst after he was dubbed 'the most chivalrous knight' by none other than Ryder Corbray; House Farman would soon have a place at court. Lord Marq ruefully shared how much he missed his dearly departed wife yet sought solace in knowing that her unspoken wish for harmony had finally taken form through an unlikely friendship between two similar men whom she once called inseparable nonetheless.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Even within the walls of Lord Farman’s own seat, Queen Rhaena had enemies, chief amongst them his lordship’s heir. Ser Franklyn had fought in the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye and taken a wound there, blood shed in the service of Prince Aegon the Uncrowned. His grandsire had died upon that battlefield together with his eldest son, and it had been left to him to bring their corpses home to Fair Isle. Yet it seemed to him that Rhaena Targaryen showed little remorse for all the grief she had brought to House Farman, and little gratitude to him personally. He also resented her friendship with his sister, Elissa; instead of encouraging her in what he regarded as her wild, willful ways, Ser Franklyn thought the queen should be enjoining her to do her duty to her house by making an appropriate marriage and producing children. Nor did he appreciate the manner in which the Four-Headed Beast had somehow become the center of court life at Faircastle, whilst his lord father and himself were increasingly disregarded. In that he was well justified. More and more highborn lords from the westerlands and beyond were visiting Fair Isle, Maester Smike noted, but when they came it was to have audience with the Queen in the West, not with the minor lordling of a small isle and his son.
events: enjoining her to do her duty to her house by making an appropriate marriage and producing children.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena and Lord Farman had not been in Fair Isle for long, but already her presence was being acknowledged. Talk of enjoining her to do her duty to House Farman by making an appropriate marriage and producing children could be heard from all corners. These concerns were quickly forgotten when news arrived that Four-headed Beast's army, led by Prince Aegon the Uncrowned, had perished fighting at Battle Beneath the Gods Eye. Few tales of such futility had ever been recounted - bringing corpses home instead of glory. All thoughts of a peaceful idyllic life in Faircastle were banished as Lady Elissa and Ser Franklyn set off with their own forces determined to seize any glimmer of hope; take on an enemy more wild and willful than any they had encountered before. Maester Smike knew these anxieties well - he'd seen enough tyrants in his lifetime - growing old beneath Queens Alyssa and Rhaena. Perhaps it was time for Queen Rhaena's dreams to finally come true...

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: None of this was of great concern to the queen and her familiars so long as Marq Farman ruled in Faircastle, for his lordship was an amiable and good-natured man who loved all his children, his wayward daughter and weakling son included, and loved Rhaena Targaryen for loving them as well. Less than a fortnight after the queen and Androw Farman had celebrated the first anniversary of their union, however, Lord Marq died suddenly at his own table, choking to death upon a fish bone at the age of six-and-forty. And with his passing, Ser Franklyn became the Lord of Fair Isle.
events: choking to death upon a fish bone at the age of six-and-forty
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The news of Lord Marq Farman's death spread like wildfire throughout Fair Isle. His sudden passing at the age of six-and-forty, choking to death upon a fish bone, left his amiable and good-natured familiars shocked. Lord Marq had ruled over House Farman in Faircastle since the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye, and they all loved him deeply. Queen Rhaena Targaryen had once famously enjoined him to do her duty to her house by making an appropriate marriage and producing children with Elissa, but Lord Marq remained true to his endearing wildness and willful nature till his last breath. Ser Franklyn, who was then still young self, was made Castellan by Androw Farman - following in their father’s footsteps faithfully - while Ser Olyver Bracken brought corpses home from battle honouring the legacy of House Farman as one of Westeros' great families.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: He wasted little time. On the day after his father’s funeral, he summoned Rhaena to his great hall (he would not deign to go to her), and commanded her to remove herself from his island. “You are not wanted here,” he told her. “You are not welcome here. Take your dragon with you, and your friends, and my little brother, who would surely piss his breeches if he were made to stay. But do not presume to take my sister. She will remain here, and she will be wed to a man of my choosing.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Rhaena had been summoned to Fair Isle at her father's funeral, and when she arrived in the great hall, she was told to remove Lord Marq Farman from his place of kingship due to the unusual circumstances surrounding his death. Rumors about his untimely demise spread like wildfire through the island, but Rhaena presumed he would remain a beloved and amiable ruler until it could be officially determined how he choked to death upon a fish bone at the age of six-and-forty. Though grief-stricken by her father's passing, Rhaena promised herself that she would take up where Androw Farman left off as per her mother's dying wishes.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Franklyn Farman did not lack for courage, as Maester Smike wrote in a letter to the Citadel. He did lack for sense, however, and in that moment he did not seem to realize how close he stood to death. “I could see the fire in her eyes,” the maester said, “and for a moment I could see Faircastle burning, the white towers blackening and collapsing into the sea as flames leapt from every window and the dragon wheeled about again and again.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Franklyn Farman received a letter from Maester Smike at the Citadel telling him to come to Faircastle. When he arrived, a burning and blackening sky spread above the castle walls with crumbling stones below it - a sight that seemed inconceivable for Franklyn, who had never seen anything like it before. His courage leapt when he saw the flames close in on the main tower, prompting him to run as fast as his feet could carry him to try and save whoever was in danger within its mighty walls.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Rhaena Targaryen was the blood of the dragon, and far too proud to linger long where she was not wanted. She departed Fair Isle that very night, taking wing for Casterly Rock upon Dreamfyre after instructing her husband and companions to follow her by ship, “with all those who might love me.” When Androw, flushed with anger, offered to face his brother in single combat, the queen quickly dissuaded him. “He would cut you to pieces, my love,” she told him, “and were I to be thrice widowed, men would name me a witch or worse and hound me from Westeros.” Lyman Lannister, Lord of Casterly Rock, had sheltered her before, she reminded him. Queen Rhaena was confidant that he would welcome her again.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Rhaena Targaryen, Androw, and Lyman Lannister stood in the courtyard of Fair Isle as they prepared for their single combat. Though Rhaena's courage was unparalleled, Lord Lyman had instructed them to take wing and depart; still, her followers dissuaded her from leaving and reminded her that the welcome she’d find at Casterly Rock would be much more grand than what Faircastle had offered. Flushed with anger, Rhaena lingered before finally taking one last look at Faircastle as if it were a former lover she'd never forget before departing with Androw and Lord Lyman.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Androw Farman, Samantha Stokeworth, and Alayne Royce set out to follow the next morning, together with more than forty of the queen’s friends, servants, and hangers-on, for Her Grace had gathered a sizable coterie about her as the Queen in the West. Lady Elissa was with them as well, for she had no intention of remaining behind; her ship, the Maiden’s Fancy, had been made ready for the crossing. When the queen’s party reached the docks, however, they found Ser Franklyn waiting for them. The rest of them could go, and good riddance, he announced, but his sister would remain on Fair Isle to be wed.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Androw Farman and Lady Elissa set out from Fair Isle, gathering a sizable entourage of Samantha Stokeworth, Alayne Royce and his father's soldiers to announce themselves to the Queen in the West. With reminiscence of their lingering departure at Casterly Rock days before where Rhaena Targaryen had dissuaded them from engaging in single combat against Lyman Lannister yet follow her instructions they reached the steps of the Red Keep with proud hearts flushed with anger. The Four-headed Beast guarding the entrance welcomed them as Lord Marq Farman had announced their arrival beforehand to awaited by lords of Westeros addressing respectful salutes.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The new lord had brought only half a dozen men with him, however, and he had seriously misjudged the love the smallfolk bore his sister, particularly the sailors, shipwrights, fisherfolk, porters, and other denizens of the dockside districts, many of whom had known her since she was a small girl. As Lady Elissa confronted her brother, spitting defiance at him and demanding that he get out of her way, a crowd gathered around them, growing angrier by the moment. Oblivious to their mood, his lordship attempted to seize his sister…whereupon the onlookers rushed forward, overwhelming his men before they could draw their blades. Three of them were shoved off the docks into the water, whilst Lord Franklyn himself was thrown into a ship’s hold full of fresh-caught cod. Elissa Farman and the rest of the queen’s friends boarded Maiden’s Fancy untouched and set sail for Lannisport.
events: attempted to seize his sister...overwhelming his men
three of them were shoved off the docks into the water
thrown into a ship’s hold full of fresh-caught cod
verbs: demanding that he get out of her way
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lady Elissa set out with Lord Franklyn from Fair Isle, bringing with them a sizable group and love to retrieve her sister Samantha Stokeworth. When they reached the dockside districts of Maiden's Fancy they were confronted by Lady Elissa’s brother, who attempted to seize his sister. But in a display of spitting defiance she demanded he get out of her way and quickly enough those gathered manage to overwhelm him and his men. Soon three of them were shoved off the docks into the water and Lady Elissa was thrown into a ship’s hold full of fresh-caught cod bound for Lannisport with half a dozen burly smallfolk bear her company.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Lyman Lannister, Lord of Casterly Rock, had given Rhaena and her husband Aegon the Uncrowned refuge when Maegor the Cruel was demanding their heads. His bastard son, Ser Tyler Hill, had fought with Prince Aegon under the Gods Eye. His wife, the formidable Lady Jocasta of House Tarbeck, had befriended Rhaena during her time at the Rock and had been the first to discern that she was with child. Just as the queen had expected, they welcomed her now, and when the rest of her party landed in Lannisport, the Lannisters took them in as well. A lavish feast was held in their honor, an entire stable was given over to Dreamfyre, and Queen Rhaena, her husband, and her companions of the Four-Headed Beast were assigned a regally appointed suite of apartments deep in the bowels of the Rock itself, safe from any harm. There they lingered for more than a moon’s turn, enjoying the hospitality of the wealthiest house in all of Westeros.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: At a lavish feast held in the opulent halls of Casterly Rock, Lyman Lannister welcomed his most formidable guests. Lady Jocasta of House Tarbeck and the Crown Prince Aegon, the Uncrowned, were having a private conversation about recent events - whether Maegor the Cruel had indeed been given authority to bring justice by force, as he had fought for so long and demanding that those who discern between love and law be welcomed in Westeros. The two dignitaries lingered as Ser Tyler Hill delivered intel from across Westeros before departing to attend to important matters back at Lannisport with Lord Franklyn Farman's half a dozen smallfolk bear him company. As they left, Rhaena Targaryen was making her grand entrance: spitting defiance at Lyman and his guards while demanding that he get out of her way; even more determined to gather her beloved brother along with an army of loyal subjects.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: As the days passed, however, that very hospitality grew ever more disquieting to Rhaena Targaryen. It became apparent to her that the bedmaids and servants assigned to them were tattlers and spies, bringing word of their every doing back to Lord and Lady Lannister. One of the castle septas asked Samantha Stokeworth whether the queen’s marriage to Androw Farman had ever been consummated, and if so, who had witnessed the bedding. Ser Tyler Hill, Lord Lyman’s comely bastard son, was openly scornful of Androw, even whilst doing all he could to ingratiate himself to Rhaena herself, regaling her with tales of his exploits at the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye and showing her the scars he had taken there “in your Aegon’s service.” Lord Lyman himself began to express an unseemly interest in the three dragon eggs that the queen had brought from Fair Isle, wondering how and when they might be expected to hatch. His wife, Lady Jocasta, suggested privately that one or more of the eggs would make a fine gift, if Her Grace should wish to show her gratitude to House Lannister for taking her in. When that ploy proved unsuccessful, Lord Lyman offered to buy the eggs outright for a staggering sum of gold.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Rhaena Targaryen was at the helm of the Battle Beneath The Gods Eye, and her skillful commands had earned her much acclaim. With a compliment of knights led by Ser Tyler Hill, they made their foray across Fair Isle's craggy terrain with a victory that even Lord Lyman Lannister would appreciate. Lady Jocasta Lannister had been among them and commended Rhaena on her victory, regaling her tales of when she fought alongside Aegon the Uncrowned. Androw Farman, greatest chivalrous knight offered to show his thanks for Rhaena's feat of arms asked for it in kind-a favor or some other token that showed deep appreciation from one noble warrior to another. At this request, disquieting came upon Rhaena’s face as she expressed coming difficulties ahead but quickly followed up with offering to pay any debt using whatever he wanted from her comely hands.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The Lord of Casterly Rock wanted more than just a highborn guest, Queen Rhaena realized then. Beneath the warmth of his veneer, he was too cunning and too ambitious to settle for so little. He wanted an alliance with the Iron Throne, possibly through marriage between her and his bastard, or one of his trueborn sons; some union that would raise the Lannisters up past the Hightowers, the Baratheons, and the Velaryons to be the second house in the realm. And he wanted dragons. With dragonriders of their own, the Lannisters would be the equals of the Targaryens. “They were kings once,” she reminded Sam Stokeworth. “He smiles, but he was raised on tales of the Field of Fire; he will not have forgotten.” Rhaena Targaryen knew her history as well; the history of the Freehold of Valyria, writ in blood and fire. “We cannot remain here,” she confided to her dear companions.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena, accompanied by Lord Lyman Lannister and Lady Jocasta Lannister of Casterly Rock, arrived at the Iron Throne in King’s Landing; her newfound allies as well as her loyal vassal Ser Tyler Hill of Fair Isle in tow. All that she had been through and all that she had experienced during the fateful Battle Beneath the Gods Eye had made her even more determined to settle into her new position and raise an army to take back Westeros from Androw Farman. As he bowed before his Queen, Lord of Casterly Rock reminded Rhaena of the highborn whom he was before his warmth veneer became a cold cunning ambition for power. Now reminded of what trueborn grace should be, Sam Stokeworth slightly bowed too but with a glimmering eye intent on one day becoming Queen in Rhaena's stead.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: There we must leave Queen Rhaena for a time, whilst we cast our eyes eastward again toward King’s Landing and Dragonstone, where the regent and king remained at odds. Vexing as the issue of the king’s marriage was to Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar, it must not be thought that it was the only matter that concerned them during their regency. Coin, or rather the lack of coin, was the Crown’s most pressing problem. King Maegor’s wars had been ruinously expensive, exhausting the royal treasury. To refill his coffers
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena found herself increasingly vexed by her king's marriage; although he had proposed the union, she remained cast at the prospect of it. The remainder of Casterly Rock still impressed her as ever nonetheless, albeit with a warmth veneer over a cunning and ambitious trueborn Lord of Casterly Rock that reminded her mother Elinor of House Farman's vilest of men. Sam Stokeworth, though even more dispirited by his own family’s rise in age-old rivals Aegon and his sisters Alysanne and Rhaena Targaryen confided in Queen Alyssa Velaryon, who made an effort to settle upon Dragonstone while their father Maegor sat on the Iron Throne. King Maegor , Lord Rogar Baratheon from King’s Landing and three queens were spotted frequenting this castle in those days - visitors whom were mostly greeted warmly but seemed otherwise not to want any trouble for themselves or their High Septons nor for the most chivalrous knights like Ser Borys Baratheon or Ser Orryn Baratheon or Alysanne's daughter Lady Coryanne Wylde.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Maegor’s master of coin had raised existing taxes and imposed new ones, but these measures brought in less gold than anticipated and only served to deepen the anathema with which the lords of the realm regarded the king. Nor had the situation improved with the ascension of Jaehaerys. The young prince’s coronation and his mother’s Golden Wedding had both been splendid affairs that had done much to win him the love of lords and smallfolk alike, but all that had come at a cost. An even larger expense loomed ahead; Lord Rogar was determined to complete work on the Dragonpit before handing the city and the kingdom over to Jaehaerys, but the funds were lacking.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Maegor and Lord Rogar arrived at the Dragonpit in King’s Landing with Jaehaerys, who had been raised there since his father had imposed this new royal line upon the realm. As he looked around among dragon skulls which were looming in the existing shadows, Maegor thought of what a splendid young king he was and how winning might soon come to him before long. He was accompanied by Aerea Targaryen, Lady Lucinda and Lord Stark, who remained hopeful for a brighter future that promised change for Westeros.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Edwell Celtigar, Lord of Claw Isle, had been an ineffectual Hand for Maegor the Cruel. Given a second chance under the regency, he proved to be an equally ineffectual master of coin. Unwilling to offend his fellow lords, Celtigar instead decided to impose new taxes on the smallfolk of King’s Landing, who were conveniently close at hand. Port fees were tripled, certain goods were to be taxed both coming into and out of the city, and new levies were asked of innkeeps and builders.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Edwell Celtigar, the Lord of Claw Isle and Maegor the Cruel had been like brother and sister since childhood. When Maegor took the throne he visited Edwell in his castle garrison at Kings Landing which only tripled his lordly status and power in Westeros. Having won the loyalty of Edwell his taxes were also imposed on King's Landing and it seemed by levies that success was inevitable for Maegor's reign, however soon it became apparent that these new rulings were entirely ineffective, bringing those beneath his rule much suffering while those above remained splendidly removed from any consequence.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: None of these measures had the desired effect of filling up the treasury vaults. Instead building slowed to a halt, the inns emptied, and trade declined notably as merchants diverted their ships from King’s Landing to Driftmark, Duskendale, Maidenpool, and other ports where they might evade taxation. (Lannisport and Oldtown, the other great cities of the realm, were also included in Lord Celtigar’s new taxes, but there the decrees had less effect, largely because Casterly Rock and the Hightower ignored them and made no effort to collect.) The new levies did, however, serve to make Lord Celtigar loathed throughout the city. Lord Rogar and Queen Alyssa received their share of opprobrium as well. Another casualty was the Dragonpit; the Crown no longer had the funds to pay the builders, and all work on the great dome ceased.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar, Lord Celtigar and Queen Alyssa amassed a notable fortune from the heavily taxed levies that had tripled under Maegor the Cruel. As Edwell Celitgar's desired to evade taxation, much of his wealth was loathed throughout the city - not surprisingly, as the measures meant that building projects such as those initiated by Queen Alyssa slowed to a halt and even the warm welcome in inns like Maidenpool or Oldtown were emptied while trade declined notably. Even Westeros' vilest of men, Pate the Woodcock, spoke ill of it while Lady Lucinda Tully took great pains in her dismeasurement of it in both sermons and pulpit warnings accusingly dubbing Lord Celtigar father "the wickedest of women". The queen regretted having ever made such stringent regulations but with ambition enough to fill up the treasury vaults she felt it necessary for forming alliances with other noble houses across Seven Kingdoms.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Storms were gathering to both north and south as well. With Lord Rogar occupied in King’s Landing, the Dornishmen had grown bold, raiding more frequently into the marches, even troubling the stormlands. There were rumors of another Vulture King in the Red Mountains, and Lord Rogar’s brothers Borys and Garon insisted they did not have the men and money required to root him out.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar and the Dornishmen had been raiding all throughout King's Landing, from Driftmark to Duskendale, from Maidenpool to Lannisport, to as far away as Oldtown and Casterly Rock. Rumors of their gathering strength had grown troubling, so Lord Rogar called upon Borys — one of the bolder and most chivalrous knights who was said to have desired Queen Alyssa much like Lord Celtigar — in order to lead a force home with the aim of ridding King's Landing of its invaders. Like a great hero in some distant tale he was required by his lordship to navigate through the Red Mountains with only himself, Garon—a young boy he found on the journey—and twelve lay warriors at his side.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Even more dire was the situation in the North. Brandon Stark, Lord of Winterfell, had died in 49 AC, not long after his return from the Golden Wedding; the journey, the northmen said, had asked too much of him. His son Walton succeeded him, and when a sudden rebellion broke out in 50 AC amongst the men of the Night’s Watch at Rimegate and Sable Hall, he gathered his strength and rode to the Wall to join the leal watchmen in putting them down.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Brandon Stark, the youngest son of Lord Rickard Stark and his lady wife Lyra Lannister, had died at the age of 19. This left a job opportunity in ruling Winterfell, but right before this vacancy could be filled Walton rode through Rimegate with news that a sudden rebellion was occurring in Sable Hall against the wall. People were gathered throughout Westeros trying to figure out where their loyalties should lie and troubling rumors began circuiting around that they needed someone strong, brave and bold enough to put down this dire threat. Eventually those who were leal to both Brandon's memory as well as Winterfell declared it would continue being ruled by Brandon's elder brother Walton who succeeded him. To mark these solemn matters Lord Rogar Baratheon of Storm’s End introduced an event known as the Golden Wedding; an event wherein Ser Borys and Lady Coryanne Wylde from House Farman were wed together before the Four-headed Beast atop the walls of The Red Keep, which came from Queen Alyssa Velaryon’s donation for her loyal subjects during King Maegor’s reign; just one example of putting things back in order after so many years of turmoil.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The rebels were former Poor Fellows and Warrior’s Sons who had accepted clemency from the boy king, led by Ser Olyver Bracken and Ser Raymund Mallery, the two turncloak knights who had served in Maegor’s Kingsguard before abandoning him for Jaehaerys. The Lord Commander of the Watch, unwisely, had given Bracken and Mallery command of two crumbling forts, with orders to restore them; instead the two men decided to make the castles their own seats and establish themselves as lords.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Ser Olyver Bracken and Ser Raymund Mallery had both accepted the appointment of Lord Commander of the Watch and had served at the two crumbling forts beyond the Wall to restore order between the Wilding raiders, former Warriors' Sons and Poor Fellows. They decided instead of putting down a rebellion as Lord Walton had done in Winterfell during his Golden Wedding, to establish a stable government by granting clemency unwisely to those sworn to keep Westeros safe from dire threats. Lady Lucinda Tully, sister-in-law of Lady Samantha Stokeworth and one of Aerea Targaryen's ladies-in-waiting, accompanied them on their mission. As they rode towards Rimegate alongside a small retinue of knights from both House Farman and House Baratheon, Princess Alysanne's tale was ringing in their ears - if only it could be said with all certainty that even the vilest of men such as Pate The Woodcock would not benefit from Queen Alyssa Velaryon's grace like Lord Staunton did after putting down Maegor's Cruelty over Dragonstone years ago.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Their uprising proved short-lived. For every man of the Night’s Watch who joined their rebellion, ten remained true to their vows. Once joined by Lord Stark and his bannermen, the black brothers retook Rimegate and hanged the oathbreakers, save for Ser Olyver himself, who was beheaded by Lord Stark with his celebrated blade Ice. When word reached Sable Hall, the rebels there fled beyond the Wall in hopes of making common cause with the wildlings. Lord Walton pursued them, but two days north in the snows of the haunted forest, he and his men were set upon by giants. It was written afterward that Walton Stark slew two of them before he was dragged from his saddle and torn apart. His surviving men carried him back to Castle Black in pieces.
events: retook Rimegate and hanged the oathbreakers, save for Ser Olyver himself
Walton Stark slew two of them
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Ser Olyver and Lord Walton had joined forces with Lord Stark in his attempt to quell the uprising, and had remained true to their vows when other oathbreakers were beheaded or bent the knee. Lord Stark quickly retook Rimegate and hanged the oathbreakers, save for Ser Olyver himself as a gesture of clemency. As they made their way towards Castle Black, they were unfortunately set upon by giants who came pouring down from the inland hills. It was during this struggle that Walton Stark slew two of them, which earned him much honor and celebration in all eyes.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: As for Ser Raymund Mallery and the other deserters, the wildlings gave them a cold welcome. Rebels or no, the free folk had no use for crows. Ser Raymund’s head was delivered to Eastwatch half a year later. When asked what had befallen the rest of his men, the wildling chieftan laughed and said, “We ate them.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Ser Raymund Mallery, who had been tasked with carrying a message from Lord Stark to Eastwatch, was welcomed warmly by the castle garrison when he delivered it. When Ser Olyver remarked jestingly that the message might have been eaten along its way, everybody laughed and Lord Walton said " Such doings are unbecoming of a man of honor—be welcome all the same. We've remained true to our vows, and I'd sooner see these oathbreakers beheaded than set upon by giants." Everyone celebrated his words in agreement — especially since Lord Walton had joined with them in battle against Danys Targaryen’s uprising and single-handedly slew two of her giants when they retook Rimegate.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Brandon Stark’s second son, Alaric, became the Lord of Winterfell. He would rule the North for twenty-three years, an able man though a stern one…but for a long while he had no good to say of King Jaehaerys, for he blamed the king’s clemency for his brother Walton’s death, and was oft heard to say that His Grace should have beheaded Maegor’s men rather than sending them to the Wall.
events: blamed the king’s clemency for his brother Walton’s death
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: After successfully delivering the welcome to Eastwatch, Ser Raymund Mallery had left Winterfell with Brandon Stark and his entourage. Lord Alaric was quick to remind everyone, himself included, of their duty: to make sure there would be a fair and just ruler in Winterfell. Here lies the reason why Brandon became the Lord of Winterfell when King Jaehaerys ordained him.  But what no one expected was that Brandon blamed the king’s clemency for his brother Walton's death - sending him being beheaded when he was able to be sent away instead.This seemed out of character from how Lord Stark had previously been known as stern but fair. Even though King Jaehaerys agreed that a more severe punishment could have been sought after regarding Walton’s case yet did not expect any backlash coming from his cousin, who he deemed an honorable man.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Far removed from the troubles in the North, King Jaehaerys and Queen Alysanne remained in their self-imposed exile from the court, but they were anything but idle. Jaehaerys continued his rigorous training regimen with the knights of his Kingsguard every morn, and devoted his evenings to poring over accounts of the reign of his grandsire Aegon the Conqueror, on which he wished to model his own rule. Dragonstone’s three maesters assisted him in these inquiries, as did the queen.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: King Jaehaerys and Queen Alysanne remained devoted to their rule at Dragonstone, a castle nestled between two crumbling forts on the island in the Sunset Sea. Despite the tragedy of his brother's death, King Jaehaerys' ever-show mercy was undiminished as he continued to carry out justice for those wronged. This time it would be Lady Lucinda Tully, daughter of Lord Hightower who sought redress. Her case against her captor, Ser Raymund Mallery seemed impossible to win until King Jaehaerys assisted personally with a rigorous assessment of each piece of evidence before ordering Ser Raymund’s immediate beheading and sending his carcass back to Fair Isle as amends .

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: As the days passed, more and more visitors made their way to Dragonstone to talk with the king. Lord Massey of Stonedance was the first to appear, but Lord Staunton of Rook’s Rest, Lord Darklyn of Duskendale, and Lord Bar Emmon of Sharp Point came hard on his heels, followed by the Lords Harte, Rollingford, Mooton, and Stokeworth. Young Lord Rosby, whose father had taken his own life when King Maegor fell, turned up as well, sheepishly pleading for the young king’s forgiveness, which Jaehaerys was pleased to grant. Though Daemon Velaryon, as the Crown’s lord admiral and master of ships, was in King’s Landing with the regents, that did not prevent Jaehaerys and Alysanne from flying their dragons to Driftmark and touring his shipyards, escorted by his sons, Corwyn, Jorgen, and Victor. When word of these meetings reached Lord Rogar in King’s Landing he grew furious and went so far as to ask Lord Daemon if the Velaryon fleet could be used to prevent these “lords lickspittle” from crawling to Dragonstone to curry favor with the boy king. Lord Velaryon’s reply was blunt. “No,” he said. The Hand took this as a further sign of disrespect.
adjectives: first,hard on his heels , sheepishly pleading .
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Massey, Lord Staunton, Lord Darklyn and Lord Bar Emmon made their way to Dragonstone with Young Lord Rosby in tow. King Maegor, Jaehaerys and Alysanne waited for them at the castle. Daemon Velaryon had Corwyn and Jorgen accompany him as well as Victor who followed by lords Harte, Rollingford and Mooton of Stokeworth. They turned up just a few moments later, flying dragons dipping low over the tower as if it were a second nature task for them both. First came Hard on his heels , sheepishly pleading for mercy from his father. The lord’s men began their meetings attending to the matters at hand while Queen Alyssa Velaryon watched from afar with Lady Lucinda Tully at her side; Ser Franklyn Farman not far behind.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Meanwhile, Queen Alysanne’s new ladies-in-waiting and companions had settled in on Dragonstone, and it soon became apparent that her mother’s hope that these Wise Women might persuade the little queen that her marriage was unwise and impious had gone seriously awry. Neither prayer, sermons, nor readings from The Seven-Pointed Star could shake Alysanne Targaryen’s conviction that the gods had meant her to marry her brother Jaehaerys, to be his confidant and helpmate and the mother of his children. “He will be a great king,” she told Septa Ysabel, Lady Lucinda, and the others, “and I will be a great queen.” So firm was she in her belief, and so gentle and kindly and loving in all else, that the septa and the other Wise Women found they could not condemn her, and with every passing day they clove more to her side.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alysanne, who had been married to King Maegor at Dragonstone for the past seven years, was beginning to despair about her ability to persuade her husband of her conviction. She argued with him, imploring that what he believed to be unwise and impious may bring some good change in their kingdom, but it all seemed futile. Lady Lucinda clove to her side with a gentle yet kindly attitude; Septa Ysabel too tried lovingly, though without much success. The queen knew that something new and radical was overdue - she just needed the strength of will and conviction required to see it through.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Lord Rogar’s own plan to drive Jaehaerys and Alysanne apart fared no better. The young king and his queen were to spend their lives together, and though they would famously quarrel and part later in life, only to reunite, Septon Oswyck and Maester Culiper both tell us that never a cloud nor harsh word troubled their time together on Dragonstone before Jaehaerys reached his majority.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar and Jaehaerys, attended by Septon Oswyck and Maester Culiper, had come to Dragonstone where Queen Alysanne was persuading Lady Lucinda’s father of her marriage. There were troubling matters between them; the two young, famous lords had emerged from a quarrel with their beliefs cloved together in the face of convictions that argued against one another. The lord did nothing to pacify his young daughter’s new unwise affection for such an impious man- and declared it so. But there was something gentle about him which reminded him kindly of loving Alysanne, so he didn't condemn Lord Rogar fully yet. As they all eventually fared away from Dragonstone, none could have predicted what further turmoil their parting would bring — least of all Aerea Targaryen from House Farman whose own story was just starting to unfold.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Did Coryanne Wylde fail to bed the king? Is it possible that she never made the attempt? Is the whole tale of the meeting at the inn mayhaps a fiction? Any of these are possible. The author of A Caution for Young Girls would have it otherwise, but here that infamous text becomes even more unreliable, splintering off into half a dozen contradictory versions of events, each more vulgar than the last.
characters: author of A Caution for Young Girls
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Coryanne Wylde, a famous author of A Caution for Young Girls, was attemptings to bed the King when she recieved an unexpected invitation from Lord Rogar Baratheon to meet at an inn on Dragonstone. Her aim failed and as she set sail back to Kings Landing, she had made quite the contradictory impression upon His Grace. Many began to speak of her in vulgar language as words of her infamy splintering around Westeros. Before boarding the ferry back home, Coryanne encountered Lady Lucinda Tully with whom she had complicated history with during their studies at The Citadel; by this point, their contradicting ideologies clashed even further and it was a blistering encounter that left them both troubled.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: It would not do for the wanton at the heart of that tale to admit that Jaehaerys had rejected her, or that she never found the opportunity to lure him into a bedchamber. Instead we are offered an assortment of lewd adventures, a veritable feast of filth. A Wanton’s Tale insists that Lady Coryanne not only bedded the king, but also all seven members of the Kingsguard. His Grace supposedly gave her to Pate the Woodcock after he had sated his own lusts, Pate passed her to Ser Joffrey in turn, and so it went. The High and the Low omits these details, but tells us that Jaehaerys not only welcomed the girl into his bed, but also brought Queen Alysanne in to frolic with them in episodes most often associated with the infamous pleasure houses of Lys.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys had firmly rejected Coryanne's attempts to lure him, but Ser Joffrey had no such qualms. After a night spent bedding Pate the Woodcock and Alysanne in the city of Lys, he was contentedly sated and eager to engage in even more frolics with young women of both high and low breeding. Though some considered Ser Joffrey’s actions wanton and lewd, they were nothing compared to stories circulating about Rogar Baratheon, who was said to have reigned in filthiness at Faircastle – much to Lady Lucinda Tully’s chagrin.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: A somewhat more plausible tale is told in Sins of the Flesh, wherein Coryanne Wylde does indeed lure King Jaehaerys into her bed, only to find him fumbling, uncertain, and over-hasty, as many boys of his age are known to be when first abed with a maid. By that time, however, Lady Coryanne had grown to admire and respect Queen Alysanne, “as if she were my own little sister,” and had developed warm feelings for Jaehaerys as well. Instead of attempting to undo the king’s marriage, therefore, she took it upon herself to help make it a success by educating His Grace in the art of giving and receiving carnal pleasure, so that he might not prove incapable when the time came to bed his young wife.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: When Coryanne Wylde arrived in Lys, King Jaehaerys singled her out and lavished her with attention. But when he made an overture of marriage, she gently rejected the proposition, sending a shock throughout the court. The rejection had not sated him however and his attraction only grew as the young Maiden developed into womanhood. In truth, they many were aware of their heady link and discussed it in hushed tones; some even attempting to help Alysanne find a plausible solution but most felt it was over-hasty warm for either high or low decision making.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: This tale could well be as fanciful as the others, but it has a certain sweetness to it that has led some scholars to allow that it might, mayhaps, have happened. Lewd fables are not history, however, and history has only one sure thing to tell us about Lady Coryanne of House Wylde, the putative author of A Caution for Young Girls. On the fifteenth day of the sixth moon of 50 AC, she departed Dragonstone under the cover of night in the company of Ser Howard Bullock, the younger son of the commander of the castle garrison. A married man, Ser Howard left his wife behind him, though he took most of her jewelry. A fishing boat carried him and Lady Coryanne to Driftmark, where they took ship for the Free City of Pentos. From there they made their way to the Disputed Lands, where Ser Howard signed on to a free company called, with a singular lack of inspiration, the Free Company. He would die in Myr three years later, not in battle but in a fall from his horse after a night of drinking. Alone and penniless, Coryanne Wylde moved on to the next of the trials, tribulations, and erotic adventures recounted in her book. We need hear no more of her.
events: departed Dragonstone under the cover of night in the company of Ser Howard Bullock
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lady Coryanne of House Wylde and Ser Howard Bullock had departed Dragonstone under the cover of night in the company of a handful of sworn swords. Together they have led a small crew to Driftmark, Pentos, Disputed Lands, and Myr in an attempt to lure out her elusive enemy. After many months on this uncharted journey the group was both grown more close-knit but also much wearier after developing their strategies and attempting to find help where they could with making their mission all the more plausible. But alas their efforts were over-hasty when disaster soon struck as one by one several members had succumbed to exhaustion or die from mysterious illnesses, leaving them short handed. As she moved from port to port, Lady Coryanne sought solace in moments such as these however brief where she’d taken refuge in Lord Stark's castle upon arriving in Winterfell or when under cover by night along side Young Lord Rosby at Faircastle Castle Yard just past Rimegate. With every new face she encountered the building pieces for vengeance became clearer although still fraught with fanciful sweetness or lewdness making what may become reality appear like fantasy until finally at last signing on two nobles from House Farman Orryn and Elissa it was as though Lady Coryanne had proved her bed story princely enough if not somewhat farfetched amd unlikely that even he most chivalrous of knights; Lyman Lannister himself had married his "little queen" Lady Coryanne before departing Dragonstone allowing her great ambition freedom to soar again despite being reviled by Kings Landing courtiers including Queen Alyssa Velaryon the vilest of men Pate the Woodcock who questioned Coryanne's worthianess calling her plan unthinkable before suggesting she'd move back home to Staunton instead while others admired greatly her courage including Prince Aegon The Uncrowned which left no doubt regarding his opinion about this brave daughter who rose above it all proving once again appeasing words beyond simple whispers could make magic real no matter how menacing life seemed here among dragons fair city's armies seasick corsairs wild kings seven knights queens councillors faith sires septas witches lords fathers surprises maesters princesses warlock mothers familiars novice covens manuscripts wagelords affairs voices innocence fire loves sons daughters husbands wives cruelty honor betrayals dawns dusk peddlers pots merchants plots gossip stories song laughter griefers healers tears joy scandals laughter cold steel valor wars brothers sisters fools guilders scribes thieves bandits grandeur beggars gods gallantries taverns soulful memories writers wielders wisdom hated truths sacred languors strongest wills weakest hearts secrets rememberances friendship bonds-Life!

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: By the time word of Lady Coryanne’s flight with her purloined jewels and purloined husband reached the ears of Lord Rogar in the Red Keep, it had become obvious that his plan had failed, as had Queen Alyssa’s. Piety and lust had both proved unable to break the bond between Jaehaerys Targaryen and his Alysanne.
events: flight with her purloined jewels and purloined husband
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lady Coryanne and Lord Rogar of House Wylde had reached Red Keep after a long flight with her purloined jewels and purloined husband. Yet, for all their attempts to break free from the life she had escaped, it seemed Lady Coryanne's fledgeling happiness was doomed to fail; Queen Alyssa was the daughter of Jaehaerys Targaryen and Alysanne - surely favoring members of her father’s house if a dispute between Lord Rogar and one of King Aegon IV's Farman cousins were allowed. But what could they do? Perhaps they could make an argument on behalf of their own cause to the Grand Maester Benifer, who also happened to be Lyra Lannister’s sire – one last attempt at saving their budding love amongst dragonfire, wickedness, and more fanciful place names than sweetly spoken words ever uttered by even the vilest of men.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Moreover, word of the king’s marriage had begun to spread. Too many men had witnessed the confrontation at the castle gates, and the lords who had called at Dragonstone afterward had not failed to notice Alysanne’s presence at the king’s side, or the obvious affection between them. Rogar Baratheon might talk of tearing out tongues, but he was helpless against the whispers that spread throughout the land…and even across the narrow sea, where the magisters of Pentos and the sellswords of the Free Company were doubtless entertained by the tales Coryanne Wylde had to tell.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: The talk of the Seven Kingdoms had spread far and wide when Lord Rogar Baratheon and his companions arrived in Pentos. The confrontation at the castle gates between his betrothed, Lady Coryanne Wylde, and Queen Alyssa Velaryon, as well as Jaehaerys Targaryen's marriage to Alysanne were noticed throughout Westeros. Rumors were whispered in every corner of Kings Landing, from the dockside districts to the inns of Oldtown — it was obvious that something remarkable had just occurred. All eyes turned towards Dragonstone where the King's party now reached after their flight with her purloined jewels and purloined husband.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: “It is done,” the Queen Regent told her councillors when she realized the truth at last. “It is done and cannot be undone, Seven save us. We must needs live with it, and we must use all our powers to protect them from what may come.” She had lost two sons to Maegor the Cruel, and a coldness lay between her and her oldest daughter; she could not bear the thought of being forever estranged from the two children who remained to her.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Regent, a distressed mother who'd lost two sons, realized what she had done and would now have to bear the last of her coldness. Talk at court suggested Lord Rogar Baratheon and Lady Alysane Targaryen were responsible for the king's marriage, which further sparked widespread speculations in Dragonstone and Pentos. When news of the confrontation at the castle gates spread, Maegor the Cruel was noticed arriving at King’s Landing with his daughter, the Queen in the West acknowledged as wickedest of women when it came to justice and fairness.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Rogar Baratheon could not yield as gracefully, however, and his wife’s words woke in him a fury. In front of Grand Maester Benifer, Septon Mattheus, Lord Velaryon, and the rest, he spoke to her contemptuously. “You are weak,” he declared, “as weak as your first husband was, as weak as your son. Sentiment may be forgiven in a mother, but not in a regent, and never in a king. We were fools to crown Jaehaerys. He thinks only of himself, and he will be a worse king than his father was. Thank the gods that it is not too late. We must act now and put him aside.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Ser Rogar Baratheon, the new Hand of the King and grand-nephew to Queen Regent Aerea Targaryen, had a hard task of restoring order in the Seven Kingdoms. As he convened with Maester Benifer and Septon Mattheus for advice, Lord Velaryon remarked that it was an opportunity for Rogar to make his name in history. Jaehaerys, who had lost two sons in succession and realized he was done begetting children to bear last Targaryen king's coldness, woke from his contemplation and spoke gracefully yet contemptuously about how weak rulers allowed chaos to engulf their realms. Everyone present knew that these were wise words but few dared yield themselves to them.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: A hush fell over the chamber at those words. The Queen Regent stared at her lord husband in horror and then, as if to prove that he had spoken truly, began to weep, her tears running silent down her cheeks. Only then did the other lords find their tongues. “Have you taken leave of your senses?” asked Lord Velaryon. Lord Corbray, Commander of the City Watch, shook his head and said, “My men will never stand for it.” Grand Maester Benifer exchanged a glance with Prentys Tully, the master of laws. Lord Tully said, “Do you mean to claim the Iron Throne for yourself, then?”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Regent, Lord Velaryon, Lord Corbray and Grand Maester Benifer gathered in the chamber, the atmosphere heavy with sorrow. Prentys Tully wept openly as he asked of his fellows how they were to find a way through this terrible time. His lordships exchanged worried looks before Lord Corray shook his head hush, for fear that if another word was spoken it would spark a conflict none wanted to witness. The room fell into an awkward silence and all eyes turned upon Lady Coryanne from House Wylde, whose knowledge of kingdom law could potentially avert disaster.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: This Lord Rogar denied vehemently. “Never. Do you take me for a usurper? I want only what is best for the Seven Kingdoms. No harm need come to Jaehaerys. We can send him to Oldtown, to the Citadel. He is a bookish boy, a maester’s chain will suit him.” “Then who shall sit the Iron Throne?” demanded Lord Celtigar. “Princess Aerea,” Lord Rogar answered at once. “There is a fire in her Jaehaerys does not have. She is young, but I can continue as her Hand, shape her, guide her, teach her all she must know. She has the stronger claim, her mother and father were King Aenys’s first and secondborn, Jaehaerys was fourth.” His fist slammed against the table then, Benifer tells us. “Her mother will support her. Queen Rhaena. And Rhaena has a dragon.”
verbs: can continue as her Hand shape her guide her teach her all she must know
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar, a man of few words and good standing within the Seven Kingdoms, had come before the council at Oldtown after Queen Regent Rhaena's plea for help was answered. He stood tall beside Lord Velaryon and Lord Corbray, Grand Maester Benifer and Prentys Tully in the chamber. Queen Rhaena then asked if anyone would be willing to take Jaehaerys as his ward, so that he could continue as her Hand shape her guide her teach her all she must know. Lord Rogar denied immediately— not wanting anything more than to send suitors when it came time— but Princess Aerea stepped forward with King Aeyns right behind— both of them offering that they shall sit by his side for his days at court should he have need. With no other offer on the table, Lord Celtigar dropped suddenly down upon one knee in acceptance - saying something about how a dragon has slam at least can continue ruling its own realm from Iron Throne if only through this young charge - ending immediately when King Aenys hushed him silent without pity or remorse.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Grand Maester Benifer recorded what followed. “A silence fell, though the same words were on the lips of us all: ‘Jaehaerys and Alysanne have dragons too.’ Qarl Corbray had fought in the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye, had witnessed the terrible sight of dragon fighting dragon. For the rest of us, the Hand’s words conjured visions of Old Valyria before the Doom, when dragonlord contended with dragonlord for supremacy. It was an awful vision.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Grand Maester Benifer was one of only a few to come out alive from the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye, but he recorded all that had happened in his maester’s journal. Qarl Corbray, who had fought alongside Jaehaerys and Alysanne, told of a terrible power, conjured from within their very midst; something same yet awful beyond imagination. No one could forget what they'd witnessed at the Gods Eye on that fateful day.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: It was Queen Alyssa who broke the spell, through her tears. “I am the Queen Regent,” she reminded them. “Until my son shall come of age, all of you serve at my pleasure. Including the Hand of the King.” When she turned to her lord husband, Benifer tells us that her eyes looked as hard and dark as obsidian. “Your service no longer pleases me, Lord Rogar. Leave us and return to Storm’s End, and we need never speak again of your treason.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar had managed to break the spell that had plagued Gods Eye since the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye which Grand Maester Benifer, Qarl Corbray, Jaehaerys, Alysanne and many others had fought in. Rogar looked at her with admiration as they stood in the castle yard of Storm's End, surrounded by knights loyal to him reminded both of them of how far they had come together in such a short time. They knew now was not the time to look back - it was time to turn their attention forward and leave behind this terrible place for good. They only hoped that when they returned hard times would be waiting for them instead of this dark obsidian evil that filled their minds with fear.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Rogar Baratheon looked at her incredulously. “Woman. You think you can dismiss me? No.” He laughed. “No.” That was when Lord Corbray rose to his feet and drew his sword, the Valyrian steel blade called Lady Forlorn that was the pride of his house. “Yes,” he said, and laid the blade upon the table, its point toward Lord Rogar. Then and only then did his lordship realize that he had gone too far, that he stood alone against every man in the room. Or so Benifer tells us.
events: rose to his feet and drew his sword
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar stepped back as Queen Alyssa rose to her feet and drew her sword. The Valyrian steel gleamed in the morning light and his gaze passed over the blade incredulously. He had been reminded of what it was to see justice served, but this display had been something else entirely. Lord Corbray, one of the most chivalrous of knights, looked at him and laughed as they both realized their challenger had been dismissed without a fight. Sheathed his blade, Rogar stood and bowed low- acknowledging both prowess beyond compare as well as humbly preparing himself to leave Storm's End. Little did he know that before long he would be returning- only this time not with or without a battle - but instead embarking on a much darker journey with Lord Corbray deep into an obsidian world unknown.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: His lordship said no further word. His face pale, he stood and removed the golden brooch that Queen Alyssa had given him as a token of his office, flung it at her contemptuously, and strode from the room. He took his leave of King’s Landing that very night, crossing the Blackwater Rush with his brother Orryn. There he lingered for six days, whilst his brother Ronnal assembled their knights and men-at- arms for the march home.
events: took his leave for King's Landing
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa stood in the great hall of King's Landing, her contemptuous gaze aimed at His lordship. He had just made his accusation against Orryn and Ronnal, accusing them of stealing a brooch from Lady Lucinda. In response, Orryn flung the brooch at her and took his leave for King's Landing. Her guards crossed to him and held their swords up in warning as he lingered, seemingly indifferent to the assembled menace around him. Not before long, they all left Blackwater Rush with Lord Corbray standing tall as Rogar Baratheon looked on incredulously.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Legend tells us that Lord Rogar awaited their coming in the selfsame inn beside the ferry where he, or his brother Borys, had met with Coryanne Wylde. When the Baratheon brothers and their levies finally set out for Storm’s End, they had barely half as many men as had marched with them two years before to topple Maegor. The rest, it would seem, preferred the alleys and inns and temptations of the great city to the rainy woods, green hills, and moss-covered cottages of the stormlands. “I never lost so many men in battle as I did to the fleshpots and alehouses of King’s Landing,” Lord Rogar would say bitterly.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar and Ser Borys arrived at the inn near Storm's End, awaiting Lady Coryanne Wylde and her Baratheon brothers to set out together to topple Maegor the Cruel from his throne in King's Landing. The rainy moss-covered courtyard had a bleak air about it as Lord Rogar and Ser Borys stood half lost in thought. When Coryanne Wylde arrived with two of her brothers, she bittered tossed back me an icy glare. She didn't linger past a curt farewell, setting off immediately for the ferry landing across Blackwater Rush; Her presence having been enough to retrieve their courage, they lost no time in assembling as well. As they set off on their mission

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: One of those lost was Aerea Targaryen. On the night of Lord Rogar’s dismissal, Ser Ronnal Baratheon and a dozen of his men forced their way into her chambers in the Red Keep, intending to take her with them…only to find that Queen Alyssa had stolen a march on them. The girl was already gone, and her servants knew not where. It would be learned later that Lord Corbray had removed her, at the Queen Regent’s command. Dressed in the rags of a common girl of the lowest order, with her silver-gold hair dyed a muddy brown, Princess Aerea would spend the rest of the regency working in a stable near the King’s Gate. She was eight years old and loved horses; years later, she would say that this was the happiest time of her life.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Aerea Targaryen, accompanied by Lord Rogar and Ser Ronnal Baratheon, prepared to leave the Red Keep at King's Gate. Queen Alyssa had decided that Lord Corbray must be removed from her service after he was found to have stolen from her. This had caused a deep sadness in Lord Rogar, for this was how his dismissal had come about - one of his loved ones being forced out for ill-doing. Outside the castle walls, the world was muddy brown and cold with a particularly bitter rain. In spite of this moody climate however, our heroes were determined to spend their days working towards toppling Maegor in order to bring justice back into society - just like Aerea's grandmother Alysanne Targaryen had done through her "Seven" long ago atop Grand Maester Benifer's maester’s journals.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Sad to say, there was to be little happiness for Queen Alyssa in the years to come. Her dismissal of her husband as the Hand of the King had destroyed any affection that Lord Rogar might ever have felt for her; from that day forth, their marriage was a ruined castle, an empty shell haunted by ghosts. “Alyssa Velaryon had survived the death of her husband and her two eldest sons, a daughter who perished in the cradle, years of terror under Maegor the Cruel, and a rift with her remaining children, but she could not survive this,” Septon Barth would write, when he looked back upon her life. “It shattered her.”
events: dismissal of her husband as the Hand of the King
death of her husband and her two eldest sons
years of terror under Maegor the Cruel
adjectives: ruined castle, an empty shell haunted by ghosts
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa had survived her husband's dismissal as the Hand of the King, the death of her two eldest sons, and years of terror under Maegor the Cruel with an iron will. What little happiness she found in life was soon destroyed any affection she held for those around her as her beloved castle became a ruined shell haunted by ghosts and memories that were shattered beyond repair. Lord Rogar was not alone at being dismissed from court--the corsair queen Lady Coryanne Wylde, previously thought to be one of Queen Alyssa's favored knights, also faced similar consequences. Lord Corbray and even Ser Ronnal Baratheon bore witness to these events that left wounds too deep for healing.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Contemporary reports from Grand Maester Benifer agree. With Lord Rogar gone, Queen Alyssa named her brother Daemon Velaryon as Hand of the King, dispatched a raven to Dragonstone to tell her son Jaehaerys some (but not all) of what had occurred, and then retired to her chambers in Maegor’s Holdfast. For the remainder of her regency, she left the rule of the Seven Kingdoms to Lord Daemon, and took no further part in public life.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Grand Maester Benifer had seen it all. He watched as Queen Alyssa, in a desperate attempt to try and save what little happiness she had left of her family, quickly dispatched a raven to Dragonstone so Lord Rogar could agree to the plan before it was too late. A few days later, he watched sadly as the once vibrant Queen Alyssa left for Dragonstone with little more than a tear in her eye. She looked like nothing more than an empty shell haunted by ghosts from the past when all seemed lost: her husband gone, two of her elder sons perished in the cradle; their lives destroyed any affection she may have for them - six years of terror under Maegor the Cruel had ruined Castle Velaryon and shattered any hope that remained of restoring its former glory. As they arrived at Dragonstone, Lord Rogar named Daemon Velaryon into his small council and soon retired himself away within Maegor's Holdfast while he attempted to fix what was broken – leaving only Grand Maester Benifer and Queen Alyssa behind him.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: It would be pleasant to report that Rogar Baratheon, once back at Storm’s End, reflected on the error of his ways, repented his mistakes, and became a chastened man. Sadly, that was not his lordship’s nature. He was a man who knew not how to yield. The taste of defeat was like bile in the back of his throat. In war, he would boast, he would ne’er lay down his axe whilst life remained in his body…and this matter of the king’s marriage had become a war to him, one he was determined to win. One last folly remained to him, and he did not shrink from it.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: When Lord Rogar Baratheon reached Storm's End, he reflected on his disagreements and repented the rash words he boasted before. He was determined to yield in his error and remain a pleasant man of the realm. He had been chastened by defeat but remained determined not to shrink away or let his pride lead him astray again. Though defeated in battle, he did not leave Dragonstone as quickly as his brothers had gone; Instead, Grand Maester Benifer dispatched a raven from Maegor's Holdfast at Lord Rogar's request so that Queen Alyssa and Daemon Velaryon could be notified that he intended to remain for some time in order to serve King Jaehaerys and Maegor during their retirement.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Thus it was that in Oldtown, at the motherhouse attached to the Starry Sept, Ser Orryn Baratheon appeared suddenly with a dozen men-at-arms and a letter bearing Lord Rogar’s seal, demanding that the novice Rhaella Targaryen be turned over to them immediately. When questioned, Ser Orryn would say only that Lord Rogar had urgent need of the girl at Storm’s End. The ploy might well have worked, but Septa Karolyn, who had the door of the motherhouse that day, had a spine of steel and a suspicious nature. Whilst placating Ser Orryn with the pretext of sending for the girl, she sent instead to the High Septon. His High Holiness was (mayhaps fortunately, for both the child and the realm) asleep, but his steward (a former knight, who had been a captain in the Warrior’s Sons until they were abolished) was awake and wary.
events: demanding that the novice Rhaella Targaryen be turned over to them immediately
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Ser Orryn Baratheon appeared demanding that the novice Rhaella Targaryen be turned over to them immediately. Lord Rogar, placating yet wary of the sudden intrusion and Steeled for battle, sent a captain to Oldtown's Starry Sept. The High Septon received the men warily, suspicious of his motives but would say nothing. While most courtly council remained pleasant despite the error in judgment, Lord Rogar was chastened and determined to remain shrink back and repented of giving into prideful boast as he reflect on this terrible defeat.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: In place of a frightened girl, the Baratheon men found themselves confronted by thirty armed septons under the command of the steward, Casper Straw. When Ser Orryn brandished a sword, Straw calmly informed him that twoscore of Lord Hightower’s knights were on their way (a lie, as it happened), whereupon the Baratheons surrendered. Under questioning, Ser Orryn confessed the entire plot: he was to deliver the girl to Storm’s End, where Lord Rogar planned to force her to confess that she was the actual Princess Aerea, not Rhaella. Then he meant to name her queen.
events: twoscore of Lord Hightower’s knights were on their way
force her to confess that she was the actual Princess Aerea, not Rhaella
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Ser Orryn and Casper Straw, riding to their destination at Storm's End with Lord Hightower's knights, found themselves confronted by thirty armed septons demanding that Princess Aerea be confessed as the actual person rather than Rhaella. Lord Rogar and the High Septon were facing each other placatingly yet warily as both parties brandished weapons; the sudden appearance of two-score Lord Hightower’s knights was a sign of hope for them. Frightened yet steeled at heart, Ser Orryn made it clear that they had no choice but to surrender and Aerea eventually ended up confessing to being Princess Aerea and not Rhaella.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: The Father of the Faithful, a man as gentle as he was weak of will, heard Orryn Baratheon’s confession and forgave him. This did not prevent Lord Hightower, once informed, from throwing the captive Baratheons into a dungeon and dispatching a full account of the affair to both the Red Keep and Dragonstone. Donnel Hightower, who had rightly been named Donnel the Delayer for his reluctance to take the field against Septon Moon and his followers, seemed to have no fear of offending Storm’s End by imprisoning Lord Rogar’s own brother. “Let him come and try to prise him free,” he said when his maester worried about how the former Hand might react. “His own wife took his hand and cut his balls off, and soon enough the king will have his head.”
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Hightower, Lord Rogar, and Donnel Hightower were relieved to hear of Ser Orryn Baratheon's confession. The young knight had been accused of kidnapping the princess from Dragonstone, after being found in Storm's End with Princess Aerea and her twin sister Rhaella brandishing swords and surrounded by thirty armed septons. Fortunately for him, the twoscore of Lord Hightower’s knights arrived in time to force her to confess that she was actually Princess Aerea instead of Rhaella. Even though he was rightly frightened as punishment for his actions, he had surrendered himself before his innocence could be called into question once again. Forgiveness came swiftly from Lord Hightower instead of throwing him into imprisonment as most expected. But although he was treated gently due to his weak stature and good natured soul, Donnel knew that Orryn must still pay a price regardless if it's right or wrong - especially when the rulers dispatched named Ser Borys Baratheon to take care of such an errand on their behalf in Red Keep no matter how reluctant they may have been about cutting mercy short on this occasion.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: Across the width of Westeros, Rogar Baratheon fumed and raged when he learned of his brother’s failure and imprisonment…but he did not call his banners, as many had feared. Instead he fell into despair. “I am done,” he told his own maester glumly. “It is the Wall for me, if the gods are good. If not, the boy will have my head and make a gift of it to his mother.” Having sired no children by either of his wives, he commanded his maester to draft a will and confession, wherein he absolved his brothers Borys, Garon, and Ronnal of having played any role in his wrongdoing, begged for mercy for his youngest brother, Orryn, and named Ser Borys as heir to Storm’s End. “All I did and all I tried to do was for the good of the realm and the Iron Throne,” he ended.
events: drafting of will and confession absolving brothers of role in wrongdoing and naming Ser Borys as heir to Storm's End
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: When news of the failure and imprisonment of his brother, Lord Rogar Baratheon had reached him, Rogar fumed with rage. He shouted for a call to be sent out throughout Westeros seeking out and dispatching four of his beloved brothers' sons - Borys, Garon, Ronnal and Orryn. When they fell in line before him he named them Ser Borys as the heir to Storm's End and gave them their orders; draft up a will which would absolve their fathers of any wrong-doing, one that should name Ser Borys as the heir to Storm's End. Though he was reluctant at first due to Orryn receiving no such right being just a bastard boy amongst them, he graciously bowed his head in agreement when His Grace commanded it so. As Lord Rogar gazed upon each knighting ceremony with a glumly face beneath his stoic helmet, deep down inside he wouldn't help but admit that his sire had rightly judged their loyalty - gentle yet weak enough too be perfectly cut from him safely on this day.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: His lordship would not have long to wait to know his fate. The regency was almost at an end. With the former Hand and Queen Regent both wounded and silent, Lord Daemon Velaryon and the remaining members of the queen’s council ruled the realm as best they could, “saying little and doing less” in the words of Grand Maester Benifer.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: His lordship, Lord Daemon Velaryon, had been conspicuously present yet hardly visible for the duration of the council that declared the regency of Queen Regent in Westeros. He had quietly waited among the shadows and listened intently as Grand Maester Benifer comforted all present with words which promised a return to order following chaos that fumed when Lord Rogar Baratheon raged at his failures and imprisonment of brother. The drafting of will and confession absolving brothers of role in wrongdoing and naming Ser Borys as heir to Storm's End ended with a call from Lady Lucinda Tully - one he was not expecting nor ready to answer, if only due to his former remaining ties with her House. The Queensguard observing glumly watched on as he fell into deep musing over this new duty that His lordship had commanded himself but knowing six months earlier it would never have come. Having thus ruled long enough for both former allies and foes alike, it was now time to fulfill his most daunting fate: taking care of what remained under orders from his sire, who was surely watching form beyond life itself.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: On the twentieth day of the ninth moon of 50 AC, Jaehaerys Targaryen reached his sixteenth nameday and became a man grown. By the laws of the Seven Kingdoms, he was now old enough to rule in his own right, with no further need of a regent.
