All across the Seven Kingdoms, lords and smallfolk alike waited to see what kind of king he would be.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: When Jaehaerys Targaryen, the beloved King who waited so long to rule in his own right, finally reached his sixteenth nameday and had been ruling over the Seven Kingdoms for almost a year, no one was more proud of him than Ser Borys Baratheon. He had been faithfully supporting the regency under Queen Regent Lord Daemon Velaryon and Grand Maester Benifer since before His Lordship's birth and he hoped that these days would bring about a brighter future for everyone living in Westeros. As news spread across the great continent of new events surrounding Jaeharrys' reign, from courtly matters with Lyman Lannister and Lady Coryanne of House Wylde to adventures involving mystical creatures like dragons and four-headed beasts on distant islands, Lord Rogar Baratheon eagerly looked ahead to see what further accomplishments this young king could achieve during his twentieth or even ninth year.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: *1 It should be noted, lest we be charged with omission, that there was a fourth queen in Westeros in 50 AC. The twice-widowed Queen Elinor of House Costayne, who had found King Maegor dead upon the Iron Throne, had departed King’s Landing after Jaehaerys’s ascent. Dressed in the robes of a penitent and accompanied only by a handmaid and one leal man-at-arms, she made her way to the Eyrie in the Vale of Arryn to visit the eldest of her three sons by Ser Theo Bolling, and thence to Highgarden in the Reach, where her second son had been fostered to Lord Tyrell. Once satisfied of their well-being, the former queen reclaimed her youngest boy and repaired to her father’s seat at Three Towers in the Reach, where she declared she would live quietly for the remainder of her life. Fate, and King Jaehaerys, had other plans for her, as we shall relate later. Suffice it to say that Queen Elinor played no role in the events of 50 AC.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: After Lord Tyrell had departed, Queen Elinor and King Maegor made their way to Westeros' Kings Landing for the long awaited ascendance of Jaehaerys. Accompanied by Ser Theo Bolling and a few other Knights of the Kingsguard, they were dressed in all their finery as befitted an event of this grandeur. As soon as his coronation at the Iron Throne was complete, Jaehaerys took charge of his own rule and set about repairing the Seven Kingdoms that had been broken for so many years. With each Lord he visited: Eyrie in The Vale of Arryn; Highgarden in The Reach; Three Towers on Claw Island; and even Rook’s Rest on Driftmark - his good nature was well known to foster friendship in all corners, so much so it only earned him goodwill when he later declared barring fealty to any one house in favour of collective loyalty at large. His Grace may have played a role in events still yet to relate but what can't be omitted is Aegon's fabled Dreamfyre headered happily through Westeros - a sign seen faraway throughout Seven Kingdoms - one declaring his reign forever more powerful than any before him.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: *2 Certain copies of A Wanton’s Tale include an additional amorous episode wherein Lord Rogar himself has carnal knowledge of the girl “all through the night,” but these are almost certainly a later addition by some lustful scribe or depraved pander.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar had been charged by the ascendant King Jaehaerys to include all details of the events that helped foster his ascendance. To do so, he traveled far and wide and met many influential people on this journey. Lord Rogar was an ambitious man who never let opportunity slip him by often times committing amorous, lustful and even depraved acts in addition to simply pander to those higher up than himself. The King kept a close eye on Lord Rogar's activities therefore making sure not to omit any important fact from his scribe; for some stories he ordered Lord Rogar to find would only be heard from his lips and could relate later alongside other characters such as Lady Lucinda, Aerea Targaryen or Samantha Stokeworth in the grand tapestry of events that now existed within Westeros.

07-A Surfeit of Rulers.paragraph: *3 It is said that many years later, when King Aegon IV was in his cups, someone raised the matter in his presence. His Grace supposedly laughed and stated his conviction that if Lord Rogar were no fool he would have instructed all of the maidens sent to Dragonstone in 50 AC to bed the young king, since the Hand could not have known which of them Jaehaerys would prefer. This infamous suggestion has taken root amongst the smallfolk, but it is unsupported by proof of any sort and may be safely dismissed.
07-A Surfeit of Rulers.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar had taken root in the affections of King Aegon IV, who had instructed his confidante to raise Jaehaerys as his own son. This provided an addition to the king's already amorous and carnal bedchamber. As Lord Stark could attest from first-hand experience, Lady Lucinda of House Tully was also once among those unsupported by law that were bedded by the king - a situation which was eventually dismissed. On Dragonstone, where two sisters and three queens were said to have been born along with Prince Aegon the Uncrowned, Lord Rogar continued his depraved ways with further conquest of those whose names go unspoken. Streams of delight he sought wherever he went; vilest of men only one step away from becoming pander of a tyrant and scribe for unsavory tales yet untold.
